Обзор на Risen 3: http://steamcommunity.com//id/thgttg_marvin/recommended/249230

Risen 2: Dark Waters является почти прямым продолжением оригинала.

Сюжет продолжает историю Безымянного Героя, который за неизвестное время успел отрастить волосы, бороду, потерять глаз и обзавестись харизмой. После событий первой части, в которой  Герой пленил Огненного Титана, человечество оказалось на грани существования. Целью Безымянного стал один из Лордов Титанов - Мара, которая, при помощи осьминого-подобного существа Кракена, потихоньку уничтожает корабли Инквизиции.
Первой задачей ГГ становится проникновение в ряды пиратов, у которых есть оружие для борьбы с Марой. Помогает ему в этом Бэтти - бывшая владелица трактира на Фаранге и дочь капитана Стальная Борода, к которому и направляется наш герой.

Мир игры очень сильно изменился. На замену Мечу, Луку и Щиту пришли Шпаги, Сабли и Пистолеты.  Такой резкий переход из одной эпохи в другую почти никак не объясняется...

Первые 2-3 часа могут показаться очень скучными. Во первых это из-за того, что вас держат в рамках сюжета, который не позволит вам покинуть остров, пока вы не выполните все необходимые задания, а во вторых - из-за малого количества самих заданий... Однако после второй локации игра начинает расцветать.

Игра заметно прибавила в масштабе. Вместо одного острова теперь целый Архипелаг, поделённый на островные и береговые локации. Между ними вы можете перемещаться совершенно свободно с помощью своего личного корабля. Плавать на нём, как в AC4: Black Flag, вам не дадут, но это на само деле не нужно, Risen - игра не про часовое стояние за штурвалом.

В каждой локации вас всё также ждёт море квестов, которые стали ещё интереснее. В пример я могу привести квест, в котором нужно помочь кандидату стать вождём и сюжетный отрывок на острове Воров, в котором вам придётся встретить мирное поселение Карлов (я знаю, что в Risen 2 они называются своим оригинальным названием Гномы"
date: но "Карлы" мне привычнее...). Интерес к квестам прежде всего вызывает появившийся в игре Юмор

reviewText:
I started Risen 2 straight after completing the original Risen, which I greatly enjoyed. First off I'd like to point out that Risen 2 has made some vast improvements in certain areas: the graphics, layout, fast travel and I haven’t got stuck in a jump animation once (Which was a regular occurrence in the original) Along with a range of other things.
But despite all of the improvements that have been made, one thing lets this game down for me. The combat. In Risen 1, the combat was difficult, but once you got the hang of each type of enemy it was a difficult but rewarding system. Risen 2 handles human combat (player vs human AI) well and is a little reminiscent of Risen 1 (Maybe even a little better) But the animal combat (Player vs anything non-humanoid) is painful. There's no better way to describe it, you cannot block or interrupt animals attacks, you're forced to either dodge and bunny hop around like crazy or just burn through health items  simply to stay alive.
I really would like to recommend this game, but it's just not enjoyable having to fight packs of wild boar while getting rammed repeatedly by whichever one you’re not currently dodging.
I would suggest you try Risen 1, which has its own flaws, but I still found significantly more enjoyable than this.

reviewText:
As player who finished all Gothic and Risen games I have to say I loved the game. At first I did not liked it, and thought fighting system is bad, but as I was playing longer opposite showed to be true. I have found melee tactitcs almost for all enemy types. And only melee skill I learnt for most of the game was kick, I was playing as woodoo thief. When I read reviews that they say you have to spam mouse 1 clicking in melee I have to feel bad about them because spamming is viable only in realy rare ocassions. Agaisnt some enemies works blocking, agaisnt some not (there are even some enemies which you can't block, sadly one of them is enemy where they are trying to learn you blocking via tips :-) ). When blocking fails, try kicking or dodging. And so on. You have to use your brain, see enemies patterns and use them agaisnt them. And even when you don't like it, there is other way to enjoy the game. You can use firearms, by joing right faction. And this si lots of fun as well, and it is way easier. Another contributin to fighting in general are dirty tricks, you can throw sand/salt to enemy eyes, so you get free hit, if done succesfully. Later you can even use parrot to distract your enemies for longer periods of time. Woodoo gives you adventage in fight as well, if you choose woodoo instead of firearms. Of course as in most RPG game, luring out enemies one by one is the way to go most of the time.

Another thing I liked about the game was, that  it made laught many, many times. Especially some mission fullfiled using woodoo were amazing. Another good thing is that you have companion of your choice availabe due to most of the game, which makes fighting easier as well. Story was  somehow predicitble, but still fun.

I haven't encountered any bugs, except one minigame seemed to be as hard on normal as on hard (on easy it was easier), but maybe it was not bug. And some achievments does not unlock. One complain I will have about the game is that some skills seemed to be underused. For example great idea with trained monkey. Yes it pays for itself, but could be used way more during the game. Weapon smithing and gun smithing seemed to be pretty much useless, taking into account price of recepies and materials, with exception with use to forge legendary weapons. Another complain will be that there was no normal fighting teacher on the second island, or at least I did not  found him.

As for the replaybility, you can play it once using woodoo, and once using fire arms.  Solution to some quest (mainly main story quest) will be different. And fighting is different as well.

I wil reccomend RIsen 2 to all gothic fans, because as one of them I love it.

reviewText:
I really, really like this game.

I played it back when it was released on xbox360 (rented it), and really had a good time playing it, but didn't know if I wanted to spend $40 or whatever on it at that time.

Then I found it on sale on Steam, for dirt cheap, and having progressed farther than I did when I had rented it, in hindsight I would now say that that $40 might have been well spent.

If you are going into to it looking for a triple-A title like Assassin's Creed or Skyrim, you are probably going to be a little dissappointed.  However, if you go into it not expecting it to strictly adhere to standards set by other titles, looking for something similar to Skyrim but focused on pirates and voodoo instead of dragons and magic, you might be rather surprised with what you find.  I find the voice acting somewhere between entertaining to quite good.  The tropical ambiance, settlements (Inquisition, pirates, and savages), and wildlife look great.  The story is interesting for the most part (I found myself to be more inclined towards free-roaming and side-questing).

So in conclusion, if you are like me and actually enjoyed Two Worlds 2, I think that you would also have a great time with this.  Ironic to end a review by compairing it to another game when I just tried to impress upon those reading to NOT do exactly that when going into it, but there you have it. :D

10/10 Would contridict myself in a review and post it anyway again

reviewText:
The plot may be weak but that was not the reason I stopped playing.
The combat system is terrible. Why take a genuinely good one from the prequel and demolish it?
The dialogues are cheesy at best, infantile at worst.
The skill system is confusing at first and disappointing later. Magic is dumbed down to about three effects, some of which you have to recraft every time. The alternative would be firearms, where you press a button to automatically aim and roll a die whether you hit and subsequently wait for the cooldown to wear off.
I really liked Risen 1, this one is pretty unbearable. The only Pro is that it looks nice.

reviewText:
This game sucks.

Even for a 2010 title, the game mechanics and overall story are found lacking. The only few things that make this game even qualify for the RPG genre are the functions of Lockpicking, Smithing, and that it is single player.
The dialogue options are incredibly basic, the tutorial time totals around 1.5 hrs, and the lack of being able to kill any non-hostile NPC's devalues the game. Instead, you can knock out an NPC (such as the Worker, who is unarmed) and they will crouch for about a minute before getting right back up. Similarly, when you try to assault the town guards, they quickly defeat you and you get back up, in additon to losing 50 'Honor' points. These aspects make the game feel very restrictive.

The one decent thing about Risen 2 is its art and graphic design, which mostly applies to specific objects like the first ship you sail on. In terms of facial design and resolution, both are low.

To be completely honest, I only ever finally installed it just to get the Steam Trading Cards it has.

reviewText: Unimaginative and tiresome RPG that has you running back and forth in the traditional style, doing chores for unimportant people in an effort to build up enough experience points to buy your way out of the opening scenario, which sucks.  You'll end up having to play the opening chapter several times just to avoid making a few easy mistakes which prevent you from getting past a bottleneck, thus fencing off the rest of the game from you.  Unless you can do enough great deeds to convince the pirate captain to take you with him, you might as well just give up, and it really does all hinge around that.  Tip: don't introduce yourtself to the pirate captain until you have finished all the quests in chapter one, or you will lose the use of his daughter as a co-fighter.  Or just blast your way through and learn this for yourself and have to play the first chapter several times over to get it right.  It's just too dull to bear repeat plays.\n\nMore bottlenecks await, they've chosen that path for this second instalment.  I find myself pecking at this game from time to time as slight enthusiasm returns.  There's a mild humour, but nothing you'd miss if it wasn't there.  Some bugs too, preventing you from completing a couple of quests at least.  Voodoo pirates might make slick viewing in family adventure films (a la Walt Disney) but in games like this, where people play in their own private world, they just don't roll like they ought to.

reviewText:
This is a classic semi-open world exploration based action RPG in the Gothic/Arcania tradition, except that this time you get gunpowder, voodoo and pirates instead of magic, inquisitors and orcs/demons. The backdrop is nonetheless equally epic (you could interpret all this as the events taking place in a different part of the world of Gothic, somehwat later), and you still get to make significant choices which  influence gameplay based around factions selection. FInally, there are memorable characters with whom you will share many sarcastic conversations.

Two playthroughs are advised, you'll see why!

NB: Some reviewers have complained about the combat system taking a while to get into the flow, and this is understandable. This is partly a Gothic legacy, and partly a reflection of modern RPGs where too many of what should be basic moves are only unlocked gradually throughout the game - presumably because players are otherwise assumed to be bored too easily. The difference is, here it is up to you how urgently you address the matter. If you like fencing, then you need to work on it. This is one of the reasons I suggested two playthroughs. In one, focus on muskets and thievery/exploration and side with the inquisition you begin with. In the other, side with the ... um, other guys, and focus on their special voodoo secret sauce and swordplay.

reviewText:
I would definetely reccomend Risen 2 Dark Waters. If you like playing role playing games (Skyrim, the witcher etc) like me, this is a must have. You have absolute freedom in this game, there are many islands and locations to explore and there are a lot of side-quests and other fun stuff to do. The main story focusses on pirates, but there are a lot of things going on around it. You can recruit people for your ship, buy a monkey etc. The graphics are also stunning, even though at first i had to get used to the slightly different style of the graphics, i now absolutely love it. The detail in the towns and buildings is just incredible. You can play this game hours and hours without having the feeling there is nothing to do, it's incredible!

There are however also some downsides which could have been better:
1. The combat is basically the same through the whole game, it comes down to hitting, evading and hitting again with now and then an pistol move which has to be recharged. This can get very repetetive and boring after a while.
2. There are some glitches in the game, it doesn't ruin the gaming experience but it can be annoying now and then.

If you have any questions about Risen 2 or you don't know whether the money is worth it, i will gladly answer them or help you in any way!

reviewText: Risen 2 follows the original Risen and Gothic 1&2 as entertaining and challenging 3rd person rpgs.  I enjoyed it about the same as Gothic 2 but with an ease of use not found in the Gothic games.  The controls have improved IMMENSELY since Gothic 1&2 and combat is more intriguing compared to Risen.  The story isn't the most engaging, but it is fun, including a few surprise moments.  The voice acting is good, but accompanying hand movements can be silly and repetitive.    I encountered some minor graphical glitches (swords not being in NPC's hands, for instance) but no major crashes.  The environmental graphics were quite a bit better than I expected.  The characters and their animations seem to be a slight step up from Risen.  The HUD is unobtrusive and allows for some sense of immersion.\n\nNow, I am comparing it to Risen and Gothic 1&2 because of the setting, protaganist and system.  It is not an action RPG.  It is not Diablo, Skyrim  Choices can matter to how the quests resolve and the story progesses.  There is action and prompts for traps.  Combat isn't the easiest, either to use or to survive against the monsters until a few tricks are learned.  All in all, I recommend the game if you like RPGs or wish to try one.

reviewText:
Another Piranha game - another GEM!

In the last years I´ve found first Gothic III and since then the Risen 1+2.

The gamestyle i simular - and I have found me spending around 200 hours in Gothic 3 (luckily my stay in G3 was helped by the 1 gb fanupdate - so it was brilliant out of the updatebox) and 100 in Risen 1 and so far 25 in Risen 2. And I have enjoyed almost every second of it.

There is a lot of complaining about the fighting - but to me that is one of the really strong points of this game. It is NOT all about hammering the left mousebutton. It is however all about timing and keeping the precise distance (with kicking or dodging) that suits your fighting style and weapon.

reviewText:
A true pirate RPG to make assassins creed 4 shiver in its timbers.

No npcs are too sacrosanct to assault.  Some will fall easily and give spoils, others will knock you out and respond accordingly.

The fighting require patience and timing.  The four choices Block/parry, main attack, secondary attack (musket or coconut), and kick make for a nicely animated contest of rock paper scissors.

This game is superbly voice acted with hours of spoken dialog.

Also exploration and reexploartion are big factors once with world map opens up (after the first main story arc) and you can fast travel to islands both familiar and new.

This game is a masterpiece 9.5/10

reviewText:
A good follow-up to the original.  It takes place a couple of years after Risen 1.  It was kinda wierd to go from a heavy medieval theme in Risen 1 to a heavy pirate theme in Risen 2, but I kind of liked it.

My biggest problem in the first installment was the combat and the sticky focusing.  Sticky focus is gone, and it makes a HUGE difference in gameplay for PC users.  It's much easier to control and maneuver your character once you get used to it.  Dodge roll is your friend and incredibly powerful in it's defensive capability.  Once you get the timing and the angles you won't even bother with parry.

At first I thought they pulled a 180 and made combat just as difficult as the first one but in a different way.  They took away a lot of the timed attacks and blocking that was notorious in Risen 1, and added what felt like a button mashing system for Risen 2.  Different style, same frustration.  Once you get a bit of Glory (XP) and put a few points into Blades you can get access to riposte and powerful riposte but I never bothered to build it past 6/10.  The real game changer was getting a bit of gear and access to muskets.  This made combat a LOT easier.  Dodge roll then musket shot, repeat.

There is also the addition of the companion system.  This allows you to take a companion with you for most of the game.  It's a huge help to have mobs focus on another npc or have a pack focus on you while they kill them off 1 by 1.  Overall I'd say this was an improvement in the combat system.

Equipment is a lot better in the sense that, it felt you had a little bit of choice in what you could use, at least more than Risen 1.  I focused on Thief-skill, Musket, and Toughness items but you could just as easily build a more melee centric or voodoo based class.

I feel that they improved the leveling and skill selection system as well.  Killing mobs, completing quests, etc gives you Glory.  Glory is spent to increase your main attributes: Blades, Firearms, Toughness, Cunning, and Voodoo.  Each of these Attributes affects 3 skills.  Talents that give you better abilities, both passive and active can be purchased with gold via trainers IF your main attribute is high enough.  So there's quite a bit of flexibility with character customization.

Overall I really enjoyed this game.  More so than the original, but mainly because I didn't have to wait until the end of the game for combat to be easier and the addition of the companion system.  Definitely recommend this whether you enjoyed the first Risen or not.  It's a continuation of the first game but it can be played as a stand alone.

reviewText:
Risen 2 is a fun game, but it has some faults. It is similar to gothic and some old rpg, which give it added nostalgia value. You may find the combat system lacking, and yes it's not very good, but again it seemed old timey and likable to me. The plot if fun, but again not fanstastic. The whole game is a nice gaming experience
The main problems are bugs, and random crashes the game suffers from. They seem more common on the steam platform for some reason, go figure.
Secondly, the achievments are broken. Badly, and a lot of them. For example to get many badges you'll need to complete objectives in one go e.g. kill 2000 monsters WITHOUT SHUTTING OFF THE GAME. Obviously this is a big problem, and the worst achievment fiasco on steam i have seen since Darksiders 1.
All in all, if you have nostalgia for the old times and patience for some sluncky game mechanics and designs and every now and then a glitch or crash, then get the game, it really can be fun if you let it.

A great game, i give it a 7/10

The graphics are the strongest point of this game.. Just Incredible, the ambient occlusion gives soft shadowing to every surface and it just sets a really good tone. Not to mention all the graphic effects like fog, water, gunpowder smoke.. Easily the best graphics i've ever seen in a pirate game.. Puts assasins creed to shame even black flag as far as graphics go.

But its too shallow.. Not enough depth.. Just find money and get experience from killing monsters. I beat entire game with just a musket.. Upgrading different skills have virtually no effect on the damage either.. Enemies were a joke and i never died a single time due to a boss or enemy.. You can also just open inventory which pauses it and you can take a health potion without any chance of dying.. Its just stupidly easy.  Its nice for scenery and exploration. But thats about it the combat system is basically non existant. Hopefully risen3 is better.

reviewText: I tried to stick with this game but I really just can't. Risen 2 had a lot of potential with the pirate theme but ended up tripping all over itself trying to tie everything in together. the controls are the biggest issue here. They're the worst RPG controls I've ever experienced. Your character moves as if he is locked on a grid and he reacts poorly to the keys most of the time (maybe its just me, I can be wrong here).The combat was disappointing, it had the premise of being a tactical swordplay type of game but ultimately timing is pointless when the enemies have unblockable attacks and are faster than you. What fun is an RPG game if you don't look forward to fighting? That means a good chunk of the game is already unenjoyable and lost due to this poorly designed system. Levelling up is a chore, thousands of gold and glory are required and you're barely rewarded for taking the difficult quests. The characters are flat along with the disappointing story. the loot is barely worth the time with the lack of variety. The graphics are quite outdated and tax low end computers badly despite the quality of the graphics (my low end machine barely gets 30fps with the bad graphics). The writing isn't that good as well, the humor can be funny but most of the time the jokes are shallow. The voice acting isn't exactly good either. Aside from the main characters the npcs sure sound half baked when they talk.\n\nI fear that the Risen franchise may be in too deep to redeem itself with failure after failure. 5/10. The game is painfully average and doesn't give any sense of accomplishment with its quests.

reviewText:
I would definetely reccomend Risen 2 Dark Waters. If you like playing role playing games (Skyrim, the witcher etc) like me, this is a must have. You have absolute freedom in this game, there are many islands and locations to explore and there are a lot of side-quests and other fun stuff to do. The main story focusses on pirates, but there are a lot of things going on around it. You can recruit people for your ship, buy a monkey etc. The graphics are also stunning, even though at first i had to get used to the slightly different style of the graphics, i now absolutely love it. The detail in the towns and buildings is just incredible. You can play this game hours and hours without having the feeling there is nothing to do, it's incredible!

There are however also some downsides which could have been better:
1. The combat is basically the same through the whole game, it comes down to hitting, evading and hitting again with now and then an pistol move which has to be recharged. This can get very repetetive and boring after a while.
2. There are some glitches in the game, it doesn't ruin the gaming experience but it can be annoying now and then.

If you have any questions about Risen 2 or you don't know whether the money is worth it, i will gladly answer them or help you in any way!

reviewText:
I would recommend this game to people who have already played and enjoyed PB's previous games in the Gothic or Risen series. This is probably not a good place for newcomers to get introduced to the studio's unique style of RPGs.

Risen 2 could have been so much more. For every step forward from the excellent Risen, there are several steps back. Combat, while functional, is clunkier than it should be and plays like a low rent version of The Witcher 2's combat. Parts of the game seem unfinished—some of the skills, like the promising monkey training and intimidation skills, are poorly implemented into the game. Worse of all, the dialogue and character animations seem like they came out of a game from the 90s.

So why the recommendation? For all its faults, Risen 2 still manages to capture what makes PB's games so enjoyable. Few developers craft such lush, believable worlds that are fun and rewarding to explore. While there are a ton of quests of varying quality, the game really shines when the player is just exploring new areas, with the danger of coming across enemies more powerful than you.

Unfortunately, technical issues still plague this game. Nvidia users are advised to uninstall any 3D Vision components, as it's been known to mess with framerates. Also, a simple Anti Warp" mod is needed to fix the awful and emersion-breaking foliage warping problems."

reviewText:
Risen 2: Dark Waters – the game from the German developers from Piranha Bytes. The protagonist of the first part of the series is already faced with the pirates on the island of Faranga. But now, freed Titans create storms, drown ships and sea settlements and claim the lives of hundreds of marine civilians. Here we come, the hero of Faranga, in order to save the day, and destroy the raging Mara the Titan. Our old friends will help us with this, such as the daughter of a famous pirate Captain Steel Beard, Patty.

In the second part of the trilogy, the protagonist becomes a pirate, in order to enlist the support of the local filibusters and Captain Steel Beard. The plot, as it is stuck at Piranha Bytes, banal. We are looking for treasure using old maps, swim to the islands in search of adventure, drink rum in the port taverns, fire at bottles, general are living a normal life of the average pirate. From untypical for pirates, we are destroying sea monsters created by the Titans, travel to the realm of the dead and looking for artifacts to defeat the villain. The plot - not the main advantage of Risen and Gothic series, it is simple, does not stand out, but sometimes intriguing and exciting.

Graphics became more beautiful, brighter. Beautiful tropical landscapes, ancient ruins and settlements look amazing, the graphics pleases the eye. The visual effects are better, more realistic. The monsters, characters and various wild animals looks wonderful with textures of high quality. In visual terms, it is the same Risen 1, only better. The only thing that looks bad, it's character animation, it is terrible as before.

The role-playing system has changed. There is no more magic but voodoo witchcraft, but there are guns and pistols. Now, the main character can treat the characters and convince them, he can tame parrots and monkeys and use them to steal items. Now we have many different talents, abilities and skills, their numbers literally dazzled. It's very interesting to develop and put into practice.

It is fashionable to make games easier for consumers. Risen 2: Dark Waters does not suffer the same fate. The game is very hard, the combat system is no exception, especially in the early stages of the game when we do not even know how to counterattack or use witchcraft and shoot straight with rifles and pistols. Money is not always enough: there is nothing to heal yourself, a weak weapon, nothing to pay for skills training and so on. It difficult to gain experience, and as result we cannot learn all skills in one walkthrough, it is necessary to distribute the experience points wisely, learning only what is necessary.

Risen 2 has so much content to offer, so many side quests, worlds to explore, everything. I have put almost fifty hours into this game, doing all of the side quests, a good amount of grinding and of course the main story. It's very rare these days to find a game this good that gives you that amount of gameplay.

As a result, we can say that the atmosphere of piracy transferred perfectly, as in visual terms and in terms of the atmosphere. The game is to play it. All will be happy, especially those who love the pirate theme. Yo-ho-ho!

reviewText:
A great sequel to a great game
A sequel thats different from what I expected but in a good way focusing on the often mentioned pirates(Risen 1) and the southern seas which are now ruled by a sea titan whom you will have to defeat if u ever wanna leave the southern seas and go fight other titans which I expeceted would this game be about.

Pros:
-Great story and setting
-Legendary items and weapons to find
-Beautifull locations which are rly ncie to explore
-Lots of sidequests and treasures to do/find
-Lots of unique chars even some familiar faces
Cons:
-Ballance or better unballanced
-The early game is rly challenging and unless you played Risen 1 u will have big problems beating almost anyone and this would be good if the challenging part was still present mid+ game!
-After u learn some fighting/weapon of your choice skills the game becomes way 2 easy and almost noone is even a threat to you anymore
and the worst!
-Final boss is WAAAAY 2 easy.. The only way the final boss is even a lil bit challenging is if u skipped every single side quest and never ever learned any fighting/weapon skills
-Cinematics bugs/glitches --> Most of the faces in the cinematics will be black nothing major but is rly annoying
-Bugged BUT GETTABLE achivs -.-
-Every achiv progress resets once you quit the game(Example win 10 drinking games --> you have to do them without quiting or the win counter resets to 0 and the next time u start the game if u want the achivs u have to win 10 times without quiting) so there are a few pain in the ♥♥♥ achivs which u have to do without quiting the game which isn't a problem except for 3 ultra annoying achivs which will take u 10-20mins if ur an achiv hunter like myself

Conclusion:

The quests and the storyline are kind of domb, but not as dumb as literally every main character in the game. The characters have one-liners that they repeat to no end, and it gets annoying.

I have to go back to the combat, because it's legendarily bad. It just queues your actions when another action is in progress,  and it's impossible to stop the queued actions. reviewText:
I want to enjoy this game so badly. I bought it on sale, so I don't feel too bad about my purchase, but it's a shame that there's a few bugs that just make the game unplayable, in my opinion. I've been looking for a good, open world, pirate RPG for ages, and as of R2:DW, I'm still looking. It's been sitting in my library for months for a reason.

The bugs in question are mouse sensitivity and combat, and both seem to be the result of a lazy console port. Combat is extremely difficult due to timing oddities. You see your opponent start to move, and you react to him. Good so far, right? Next, he hits you before your character even starts to move. There's some sort of breakdown between user input and character reaction. If I recall correctly, rolling around works fine in combat, so it's really just the dedicated combat controls that offend. The other bug is axis sensitivity. Ohhhh boy. This is the one that put the first and last nail in the coffin for me. It was the first thing I noticed, and the last thing I remember before pressing alt+f4 in a huff. The y-axis is slower than a snail moving up a hill covered in molasses on a hot day, and the x-axis is faster than Sonic the Hedgehog on crack. Just recently, I revisited the problem. The internet says that you need to modify a specific config file to adjust the sensitivity. As far as I can tell, that file doesn't exist in the Steam version of the game. The only one we have is a template file.

Pros? It's pretty, I guess. I like the general atmosphere.

If not for those two glaring issues, I could probably get far enough into the game to complain about the game's staleness and repetitive nature (which I have not noticed, for obvious reasons.), which everyone else seems to complain about. I might pick it up for a console at some point in the future, but right now, I can't be asked.

Before we go, here's a little ditty to cheer you up.

Yo-ho, ahoy and avast
Being a pirate is really badass
Hang a black flag from the end of the mast
You are a pirate!

reviewText:
Risen 2 is more focused on pirates than the first game, and you actually become a pirate yourself to safe the world again fighting slightly more interesting creatures and meeting interesting folk, who you later end up forgetting about.

Shifting to the more pirate kind of world, mages have been removed from the game with a mention somewhere in the dialogue as to why. Instead of mages we now have Voodoo witches, the natives living on some islands. The bows and crossbows have been removed and instead we have pistols, shotguns and muskets.

The leveling up has been changed from how it was in the first game. You now earn Glory, which kind of represents your XP. Glory can be used on the character menu to upgrade your stats. There are still trainers who you need to pay to learn spesific skills like smithing or how to do a riposte. This was confusing to me at the beginning and it took a while before I figured that I can buy skills, but need specific stat level to do so.

The graphics are rather good and modern looking, but sometimes there would be glitches where while walking towards a tree, you'd see its leaves becoming smaller as you got closer, until they were the right size. The menu screen has been changed so that you can easily access all the info you need from any selection you're looking at. This also makes the game look a bit clumsy at the beginning, if you start right away from the first game, since it is completely different.

The game itself is much more bug free than its predecessor, but sometimes you'd encounter minor bugs that don't harm playability.

Fights are still rather difficult and you'll be using quick save a lot. During my 20 or so gameplay hours I saved over 2200 times (Which was a tad too much than needed, but better save than sorry). This is also my biggest complain about the game. Using quick save creates a completely new save and doesn't overwrite the older one. This means that I had over 2200 save files at the end and the game started to load longer. Easily fixable by removing the older saves though.

Overally a great game after you get used to the new mechanics, but a lot less fantasy like when compared to the first game. If you like pirate stuff and RPG's, then this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Things I don't like about the game:
-Combat system
-The blur effects
-Some of the animations
-The minigames are awfully difficult
-Quest layout is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥: you have quests that consist of a 3 second walk and should be merged into 1 decent quest
-Can't go full Witcher on the staggering amount of willing ladies of the night

Why I recommend this game:
I'm a fanboy of the Gothic series, so go suck a ♥♥♥♥ if you don't like this game.

On a serious note, here are the things I like about this game (& the gothic series):
-Awesome world design (believable, raw fantasy environment, something Bethesda can't create)
-The entire concept of an open world pirate RPG, replacing the regular magic system with voodoo, replacing archery with pistols & muskets, ...
-The tropical, colourful environment is just stunning
-The amount of skills that aren't just passive stats like in most RPGs
-Kicking over giant crabs, because ♥♥♥♥ you crabs


It's not Gothic 2, but hey, can't have everything.

reviewText:
Well I think that one of my favorite RPG game devs is Piranha Bytes, since Gothic series I have been playing all of their releases (Gothic series and Risen).
Risen 2 is a bit different from the others is purely based on pirate adventures, but still keeps the essence from its predecessors, for example look and feel, exploring the world and always finding nice surprises, these little details are the ones that make you feel the game, not like many others just empty building shells, lifeless landscapes, etc.
I dont understand why so many people complain about the pirate thing, I mean if they know about Piranha Bytes work they would know that the pirate touch has been present since Gothic, so I'm ok with it.

In conclusion I would give the game 9/10 it is really a fun game and ok storyline, combat mechanics are not too bad, beautiful landscapes, only thing I didnt like is the lack of variety for outfits, it has plenty of weapons, fairly balanced  by the way, eventhough they seem to have high specs they are not too OP, so you still get to enjoy part of the fights.

Well if you are looking to kill some time with a different RPG game I would suggest Risen 2 Dark Waters ;)
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game isn't what I loved about Risen 1 - well written strong characters (like Inquisitor) and also all the characters in camps; mysterious, but still logic, escalating, complex story - for me one of the best; visible (not just skills but also cosmetic) progress of player's character and great music. Also realistic fighting system - with stuns, interruptions, dodges - different tactics against animals/humen/insects/other races. And cool interiors - like laboratory in monastery or the flame sanctuary.

It seems to me that the devs tried to change features that players who didn't like their games wanted to change, but what their fans loved about Risen 1 is not really there.

Yes, you can choose which island you will visit first, graphic is better, the story is still good, but there is no unknown hero  you could customize and you would be curious where it would develop - you play a well known hero who doesn't evolve in anything - he still looks the same, he talks like he knows it all, not even learning voodoo would change him to something more mystic. The islands have still nice natives/cities, but with no gradation - you just do some quests for them and that is all.

Maybe it would be better if they would use the world of Risen but not the old hero - like they did it in Dragon Age - you could meet him, but your new hero would be yours and you could do really free choices.

But still I would recommend this game - it is still a good game with a pirate theme. The fighting system is a torso of what it was before - so it wouldn't be difficult to learn it probably, but it is not rescripted, so it doesn't work as it could if it would be made new, but otherwise everything else is OK.

reviewText:
Risen 2 changes it main emphasis onto the pirate theme for the majority of the game & it absolutely pays off.

Simply put: putting the focus on the pirating theme is excellent, as this game absolutely nails the pirates theme. From the envirionments to the actual atmosphere of the game-world and its actual inhabitants, the pirating theme here is just extremely well done + the player will get immersed into the game and its world.

As always with PB's games, the level of interactivity & immersion factor is high; & NPC's run on schedules. There are choices to often make to finish quests differently, as usual.

The camera is now unlocked, so moving left or right doesn't strafe. The up-side: this makes it easier to battle numerous enemies & swing directly to them. The down-side: to strafe now, you have to hold your Secondary Action key. These control changes do take some time to get used to, if you're used to Risen 1's controls. A key for rolling would've helped, since double-tapping a direction makes your character roll - which can happen accidentally. The feel of the combat itself & its controls do again feel clunky, even though this is par for the course w/ PB RPG's since Gothic 1.

Even despite its few minor issues, Risen 2 is another really good RPG from PB & easy to reccommend.

Grade = B

reviewText: What's improved in this sequel? Early combat, graphics. story, game design/environment, quests, camera a little bit\n\nStayed the same? Movement, some of the combat (sometimes you can get attack-locked"

meaning a monster keeps attacking you so fast you cant block.. this is very frustrating) as well as the voice acting. The game bugs out as well every now and then.

Made it worse? Picking up items like food is considered stealing and makes guards angry at you even though the food was clearly there on display for visitors to take. what the ♥♥♥♥? Also the low early gold really holds you back and you waste a lot of time going back and forth between camps/bases. Lightning strikes (weather) are more like flashes and don't look good. There is a shortage of food because of having to fight so many enemies with flawed combat.

This is a early first impression "review". I just want to say that the game is very similar to the first one of the series and the combat/movement and overwhelming enemies thing is still there.

8.5/10 so far

reviewText:
I would like to finish this game, just to complete the story, but the gameplay itself is just too tedious for me to justify wasting all that time.

This saddens me, because I generally like the world and exploration. The story isn't mind blowing - but hey, Pirates, Sea Gods, and Colonial might, there's nothing wrong with any of that and it would make for an enjoyable jaunt if only the gameplay held up to allow the story to be told.

Combat is slow and uninspired. I've never found combat in a Gothic game to be particularly good, this just took the cake in terms of rigidity and slowness. It's a bit like Demon Souls with crappy controls (which basically makes the combat).
Reading a few of the other reviews, I guess I responded quite negatively to the combat as you would expect SOME sort of improvement in the combat of this series, but things have not progressed since Gothic 2. Back then there was so much NEW stuff that these games were doing, that you could accept a bit of dodgy combat stuff. But this isn't new. It's prettier, and in a different setting, but there's nothing new here.

Toward the end of my session I found myself switching on God mode, purely so I could skip through most of the frustratingly combat stuff and focus on the story and exploration. But after a few hours I thought to myself, What am I doing? This isn't how the game is supposed to be played". The whole point of this uncompromising style was that there were some places you just weren't supposed to go at the start
date: but God mode ruins that - even though I wasn't trying to break it
recommended: I just couldn't be bothered dealing with the combat system.\n\nSo if I felt inclined to destroy the unique aspect of this series
hoursPlayed: just so I could run around talking to people and gathering stuff

helpfulPercent: and the world is actually quite interesting. Kudos for that.\n\nBut I won't be getting back into this series until something changes with the combat. Enough time has passed that this cannot be accepted anymore."

reviewText: Nice RPG from the same team that did the original Gothic. And less buggy than Gothic, I only found two glitches that affected game play. Although it's a sequal, it doesn't matter if you've played Risen or not as it is in another part of the world and you don't miss much. World was enjoyable, but backwards - the end of the game was stupidly easy, unlike the first. Unlike Gothic, the world isn't quite as dangerous (shadowbeasts ftw!), but just like Gothic, there's lots to discover and explore. Overall, an enjoyable game and well worth sinking in a good few hours to fully experiance the story.

reviewText: Risen 2 is a pretty nice improvement on the original. The pirate theme is a welcome change in this RPG market of nothing but elves & dwarves, the story & characters are much more enjoyable & memorable even though the story is the standard chosen one must rise to save the world & most of the NPC models look the same. Unfortunately the combat while improved still suffers from the same tedium that the original had. Improving skills is also just as annoying as the first, you will never have enough gold & everything costs it even quite a few quests. Still while the Risen series has so far had many an issue the games are still enjoyable enough for me to recommend them. Here’s hoping for a Risen 3 & that they keep the pirate theme.

reviewText:
This game provided me with a lot of good, fun hours.  I played for 57 hours to complete (including the DLCs), 45 of which included actual save-point-to-save-point progress through completion.  I like to explore and feel like I hit every corener though, so the game itself could probably be played through in around 30 hours.

All of the islands have enough unique features to keep the otherwise island-by-island story grind somewhat interesting.  The different player upgrades, character interactions, unlocked islands and so on along the way are all rewarding.  Having one of many companions with you is also a fun feature. The story was interesting and the quest system is handled in a way that kept all of the next (of many) objectives obvious.

From owning a ship, to building a crew, locating legendary treasure, and following a story arch to save the pirate-world from a Titan, this game is a solid pirate game.  I liked that it followed a (very different atmosphere'd) Risen 1's story, continuing with the main character, a few side characters, and the same world; while shifting from a dark warrior's temple quest (Risen 1), to a pirate captain's artifact-hunt story (Risen 2).  Defeating a fire titan in #1 and then a water titan in #2 was a nice touch, which left me looking forward to at least two more titans to defeat in the future.... ?

Cons:
-The world, while nicely broken into smaller chunks, was too big for me, as compared to Risen 1.  I hate feeling like I missed a handful of treasures becuase I failed to climb every ridge, check behind every bush and trace every shore.  I finished the game with a few unfinished legendary weapons, which I couldn't all the pieces for.

-I never really felt like combat reached its potential for me.  I went from hacking at weak monsters while wearing weak gear, to hacking at stronger ones with simply better gear.  The combat stayed hard and a bit frustrating throughout, even though I upgraded my melee combat and gear almost completely.  It wasn't overly difficult, just never made me feel like I had awesome gear and awesome skills.  The moves introduced along the way (aside from power attacks), were too hard to know how or when to use, so felt like a waste of the hard-earned booty to train.

-Load times are nuts!  This is a good game for working on art, or playing a phone game on the side, as dying (which can happen easily if careless) results in a good minute or two load time.  Thankfully each island is seamless, inside and out... perhaps the reason the loads take so long?

reviewText:
If you liked Risen 1 or Gothic games, you will like Risen 2.  If you are new to the series well... you will either love it or hate it.  Risen games, like the older Gothic games, are generally viewed favorably with the exception they have some plot holes, story holes, and bugs.  Normally that would be really bad but there just aren't that many good RPGs of this type out there to choose from... and what does work, works well.  The exploration and adventure parts of this game are above average, as well as the background music.  I will add parts of this game are really stupid, and others very frustrating.... but was it worth it?  Yes, especially if you can nab it at a steep discount.  If you are looking for a simple point and click, this isn't for you... if you like a challenge and can get through the first 10 hours without breaking your keyboard then I'd say your in for a great time.  If your system can handle it, the graphics on Ultra setting are still good as of Dec 2013.

The good:  Lots of good quests, exploration, suprises, good loot, many ways to accomplish tasks
The bad:  Fights are very, very frustrating in the beginning... but yes it does get better as you go.

In closing, I'd say do yourself a favor and invest 10 hours before you give up on it.... if after that point you aren't sucked in a bit, then go ahead and call it a day as this game is not for you.

reviewText:
Risen 2 changes it main emphasis onto the pirate theme for the majority of the game & it absolutely pays off.

Simply put: putting the focus on the pirating theme is excellent, as this game absolutely nails the pirates theme. From the envirionments to the actual atmosphere of the game-world and its actual inhabitants, the pirating theme here is just extremely well done + the player will get immersed into the game and its world.

As always with PB's games, the level of interactivity & immersion factor is high; & NPC's run on schedules. There are choices to often make to finish quests differently, as usual.

The camera is now unlocked, so moving left or right doesn't strafe. The up-side: this makes it easier to battle numerous enemies & swing directly to them. The down-side: to strafe now, you have to hold your Secondary Action key. These control changes do take some time to get used to, if you're used to Risen 1's controls. A key for rolling would've helped, since double-tapping a direction makes your character roll - which can happen accidentally. The feel of the combat itself & its controls do again feel clunky, even though this is par for the course w/ PB RPG's since Gothic 1.

Even despite its few minor issues, Risen 2 is another really good RPG from PB & easy to reccommend.

reviewText:
The reviews that the critics gave this game were right.

I just can't see how people can stand up for this game, it's just plain bad.
First of all, the animations  the characters have during conversations are just disturbingly bad to watch, I mean seriously who moves there hands like that when they are talking about going down to the beach to get some washed up boxes?
The voice acting as well is very poor. Another thing, is that the quests are hard to find where you're supposed to go because it doesn't show you where the hell you are supposed to go, well this was my trouble with it. Also, your companion is usless, if you are trying to be stealthy or trying different tactics, the companions ai will ignore everying and just run around doing nothing. I was fighting a group of enemy mobs and she didnt not help at all with my fight against them, she just sat back and kept cycling through her bland dialouge, when i was about to finish off the last mob however, she decided to one shot it with her musket -_-. The combat in this game too is just so boring, theres nothing to it but just swinging your sword and waing every 90 second to shoot your musket, theres a parry mechanic too but that seemed to never work for me when i used it.

Overall my expiernce in this game was very poor, I wouldn't even recomend it for the 5$ I payed for it.
3/10 There are so many better games out there.

reviewText:
Pro:
Very easy to mod with Risen 2 Modstarter.
While cliché, the pirate theme is done quite well.
Firing guns is satisfying, it just feels right with the smoke and all.
All dialogue is voiced, and there's tons of it.
Quality of voice-acting is decent to good.
While a small part of the game, the gnome village and culture was crafted nicely.
Voodoo allows for some fun interaction (e.g. possess people).
Animals and monsters look nice and are animated better than humans.
Final battle is pretty decent.
Environments look great.
Nice weather effects.
Dirty Tricks are a cool idea, shame there's really just two of them (Parrot/Salt).
Monkey Trainer is a fun skill and should've been expanded upon (distract people/guards perhaps, help with pickpocketing)? Con:
Not enough fast travel locations.
Tedious dialogue-based travel between islands. Quite an amateurish design flaw.
Quest objective markers aren't always helpful (e.g. golden masks quest).
Characters repeat the same lines a bit too often (Just because i'm a woman...").
Human models sometimes look unnatural and animation isn't great.
Melee combat is pretty awful
date: animals and monsters can easily stun-lock you.\nRemoval of shields was a mistake
recommended: now combat seems to revolve about spamming attacks.\nDoesn't have the same mystical atmosphere of Risen 1.\nBugs: After a while
hoursPlayed: Badriya disappeared. Other players have noted missing NPCs too.\nInquisition players get the ritual knife (trophy tool) far too late

Bugs: Hotel merchants don't trust you when you enter their room.
Some terrible platforming in a few places.
Fall damage sucks and adds nothing to the game. I used the console (god mode) to speed up downward travel a few times.
You can only be a gruff white dude.
Most women are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s or half-naked. Even Patty fails to button her shirt.
Awful traps that only detract from gameplay. Why force us to keep a thumb on the Spacebar?
It seems weird that the highest Intimidate check is 90 but the highest Persuasion check is 55-60.
Dialogue aside there seems no reason not to use Verano (musket-wielding NPC).
Mechanics sometimes poorly explained. For instance

reviewText:
I've actually published a long review for this game on another website but I'll try to list the most crucial points here:


Story
Although this game is a direct sequel to the first game, it seems like all your previous choices were simply neglected. Despite the fact that the indigent hero saved the world before, he's now working as an employee for the Inquisition and is also an alcoholic. Well, since it's a game about pirates, there's that famous eye-patch cliché (alongside others, such as buried treasures), and the reason for that has to be one of the stupidest ideas I've ever seen. If you've already played the game you'll know what I'm saying. Oh, by the way, Patty is back... Anyway, if in the previous game you've created any positive expectative about her, in Risen 2 just a few moments under her presence is more than enough to make you wanna just shove her into one of the ship's cannons and fire her into oblivion.


Gameplay
The gameplay haven't changed much, except perhaps for the possibility of now being able to use firearms, which certainly makes life much easier when compared to the first game. The prices everywhere are still outrageous and the chests of loot that you find lying around are often filled with cheap and useless crap. Besides that, you may now have a companion to assist you during the battles, but the AI is extremely dumb when it comes to follow you, so it's not uncommon to fight several enemies all by yourself while your companion is making out" with a tree or something. Compared to the first game
date: the fast travel method has significantly improved too. Ah
recommended:
the main character's pocket still has the size of the universe!


Graphics / Sound
The visuals look nice (I really like the day to night transition effects) and the OST isn't that bad either
hoursPlayed: although it's nothing exceptional. As for the voice acting
voteText: somehow they've managed to make it worse than before. For instance
helpfulPercent: it looks like the main character is a pothead by the way he speaks. As for the other characters
votesHelpful:
there're moments that are meant to be sad but the acting is so awful that it makes the scene extremely funny.


Glitches
Just like in the first game
votesTotal: this one won't disappoint you when it comes to find these around
votesFunny: not to mention a few random crashes (although they're much less frustrating than on the first game). The weirdest one I've met during my gameplay happened right after I killed one of the bosses. After doing it
commentsCount: when I'd try to jump
column16: I'd keep going higher and higher (I believe I can fly). Ah
column17:
it was also really funny to talk to a floating Patty.


Overall
column18: while this game brings many improvements compared to the first one
column19: it still has a fair share of flaws (it also happens to be shorter too). To be fair
column20: it's not a masterpiece but it's actually fun if you actually buy it with a nice discount."

reviewText:
Risen 2 is a good game IMO

A sequel from the original Risen game
Well... It's kinda short game for a RPG, only took nearly 15 hours for you to complete the game
The Pirate theme make me really love this game, muskets, pistols, sabers even cannons are available in this game
I wouldn't recommend this game for people who take the lore of a game series too seriously, because it's completly different from the first game, no magic things remain in this game  Even the Titan Lord sets and the monocle are removed from the game with a nosense cause

Okay, now to the pro and cons

Pros :
+Realistic gameplay
+A decent graphic for a 2012 game
+PIRATE THEMED GAME (Cheer up fellas!)
+Free roam  Not open world, after the game ends, it will only take you to your last save point
+Beautiful world level
+A nice time waster when you got no activity other than gaming

Neutral :
=No magic things
=Somewhat too easy, yet a bit difficult
=Short gameplay time
=Lore are completly changed from the first and the third game
=Loading screen everytime you enter a different area

Cons :
-Awkward animations in cutscenes
-Optimizations seems a little bad
-Monotone quest (find this, kill that, search for)
-The dialogs seems a bit salty and awkward (again)

Score
Gameplay - 7/10 ---- Combat seems difficult when you face multiple enemies, but easy when you just face one
Story - 6/10 ---- The lore completly changed from the first game
Optimizations - 6/10 ---- Pretty bad at optimizations, be sure to turn off antialising
Graphic - 7/10 ----- A decent graphic for 2012 game, lightings seems nice and the world are beautiful just like the first and third game
Overall - 7,5/10

Notes :
If you a kind of person that take video games lore to seriously, DON'T EVEN TRY TO BUY THIS GAME YOU'RE GOING TO DISSAPOINTED
I would recommend you to buy this on steam sale (why not? saving money)
This game not designed for casual player

reviewText:
I can't for the life of me recommend this.

Coming from someone who loves open world games, who likes the idea of going forth the second you're done with the tutorial, this game isn't the option for me. I looked through the reviews here, and it says that around the third hour you'll have amassed enough experience (or fame in this game) and money where you can actually begin to truly experience it.

I'm don't get games to endure a good 3 hours of it in order to see the real meat. I want that presented to me, THEN a barrier or two has me grind through the experience.

Another complaint I have is the fact that the grinding required to do anything. 1,000 glory to start amassing skill points, even moreso after. You get 52 per monster kill.

It doesn't require a huge amount of mathematics to determine that you'll be grinding ALL. DAY.

There are other indie RPG games out there that are able to execute what Risen 2 has been trying to do. Maybe if the game goes on a major sale again, it might be worth it. But spend no more than 5 bucks on it.

Me? I regret doing even that.

reviewText:
This is probably the worst game I've ever played.

I'm not even sure where I should start with this. How did they ♥♥♥♥ up a pirate game?
There's nothing redeeming about this mess, I'd tell you the story, but after two hours I already forgot it.

Not even the graphics look good, it seems like they wanted to make something similar to The Witcher 2 with all the filters they used, but the overworld looks shallow and the filters and the overused bloom effect just manage to hurt your eyes. You can apparently just visit a few islands that in them barely have any content at all, a few houses, 5 to 10 NPCs and that's it. The animations are one of the worst things I've experienced in this generation, they are not even close to movements, and trust me you'll see plenty of them since every time a line of dialogue is spoken, the charachter talking will amuse you with them.

And, by the way, the dialogues sound like they got random people off the street to record them. Even a kid could make something better than what they choose.

But the worst thing about this is probably the combat system, if you really want to call it that. It's just a mess, there's no strategy, every ability costs too much to be bought and you'll spend the first 3 hours in this game just randomly slashing at enemies in the hope of killing them and then going back to a town to heal. And I'm not even sure if after the first terrible hours in the game it'll get better. This is neither fun or RPG-like, it's just boring, boring to the point I'm here wishing I had never payed that dollar in the Humble Bundle for this thing.

Please, please, don't buy this, why does this have so many people playing it at once? I don't get it, am I the only one that can see how unfinished and unpolished this game is?

reviewText:
I find Risen 2 as a highly underrated but great successor of Gothic 1 and 2 and Risen games (it's made by the same developers to those who do not know). In fact, I personaly like it much more than first Risen. It has many rough edges, there are visual glitches, few dialog errors (but no game breaking ones), combat is clunky and hard at the start, but that changes with more skills You learn yet it remains challenging.

I liked that opponents had their weakneses which you can take advantage of (for example: you can turn giant crabs on their back with kicking). There are often 2 or more ways to solve a quest. I enjoyed being a thief again as I enjoyed it in good old Gothic: Night of the Raven. Atmosphere is great especially when there is a thunderstorm. Locations are smaller than in previous game, but they feel more... personal, detailed and thought trough and it's fun to just explore (not to mention that it's also rewarding).

Story isn't that breath-taking, it's a classical have to save the world" story
recommended: it goes within the footsteps of Gothic saga. Characters are deeper then in Risen 1 and I found a few memorable ones which is a huge improvement from the previous game
hoursPlayed: from which I don't remember a single character (except for Patty
voteText: which is also accompaniing you in Risen 2).\n\nGraphics are (at least for me) fine looking
helpfulPercent: sometimes even gorgeous (Storms
votesHelpful: Sunrise
votesTotal: Dawn) and are not HW demanding as I could play it even on my old work notebook.\n\nI still didn't finish it after 25+ hours of gameplay
votesFunny: but so far I would give the game 8 out of 10. I can only recommend it for all the other RPG-positive players out there."

reviewText:
I enjoyed this, a good ~40 hours of adventure, exploration, story and combat. It has a major choice to make at the start that ends up branching quite significantly so there's a lot of room for replayability. This crashed on me once but with frequent autosaves it wasn't really an issue. The autosaves themselves also track quite far back for quite a number (easily 10+). Same for quick saves.

I used a controller for this as there are only a few times you need to aim unless you want to use guns a lot but even then it's quite forgiving. The few minigames also tone down for the controller, switching back to keyboard/mouse for them doesn't give you an advantage as they then ramp back up difficulty wise.

It's not necessary to have played the original but there are a few references to it here and there. The story can be completed in any order with a variety of ways to approach quests and solve problems. I found the combat quite difficult initially. I am confused by the low metacritic score. All in all this is a very solid choice for anyone who enjoys RPGs of this setting.

reviewText:
Since I own so many games I 'had' to rush through this one unfortunately. RPG's are usually to big to complete properly.

If you've ever played the Gothic games (except 4) then you actually know how combat and learning skills work in Risen 2 as well. It's pretty much an exact copy. The fights can become tedious and frustrating sometimes, especially with the glitchy/cheaty AI. On the other hand it does feel good when you finally defeat that annoying opponent.

The game is filled with quests and treasures and exploration is being rewarded. I remember Gothic 3 doing the same thing, meaning; lots of exploration and no(t) (too much) hand holding when doing quests. It gave a sense of immersion.

The graphics are colorful most of the times and fit the theme well. The whole thing can become glitchy sometimes.

The voice overs are ok-ish. They're not terribly bad. The writing is at times, though.

I enjoyed Risen 2 a lot, and you can get twice the amount of playtime if you do literally everything.

[Rating: 77/100]

reviewText: Plain and simple Risen 2 is an excellent game, with one flaw: combat. Combat goes from outright insane to ♥♥♥♥ easy and bosring over the game. Other than that, Risen 2 is an awesome game perfectly in line with other works from Piranha Bytes. In fact, I was surprised at how smoothly they managed to integrate a piratey settings with the cloak&dagger, sword&sorcery from Risen (and, previously, Cothic I and II: whose universe is technically unrelated to this one, although it does not really feel so).\n\nOverall, the game is really nice, and has an old-school feeling to it. risen 2 even caters some funny moments and the attempt at a couple of more serious ones (mostly crippled by the voice-acting, otherwise fine). The story is compelling enough and paced well enough to get you playing through all of it, there is certain (however small) degree of sandbox"
recommended: but the game plays well and it turns out to be really enjoyable

reviewText:
If your computer is running on a Nvidia driver, make sure 3D drivers aren't installed because the game will lag to ungodly proportions.

With that out of the way, Risen 2 is certainly not perfect but it has its charms of a pirate game.  I didn't play the first game, so I wasn't as horribly disappointed like some other fans of the first game.  The animation is cheap, but the dialogue makes up for it and the graphics itself is nice with the tropical environment.  Since blood and violence don't warrant an M rating in my book, the excessive swearing does end up warranting a mature rating as pirates use sailor's language to talking about women's bodies, shagging organisms, and the f-word like it's going out of style.  The side quests were more interesting than the main story, sadly, but side quests are fun to do since you will have to run around town quite a bit or backtrack during the main quest.

Gold is key here since combat is hard even on easy mode.  The learning curve is steep because you need to spend gold on learning how to dodge, parry, riposte, and other things.  Yes, you will have to spend a fortune to learn the skills necessary to survive.  Mashing X is going to be hard if you haven't saved money to learn how to dodge, parry, or counter attack.  A frustrating bit about the combat was that it took me a while to realize that going to the inventory to restore my health was a terrible idea, because the MC will have put away his sword and I had to quickly pull it out to guard.  But halfway through the game gets easier as you do a bunch of sidequests that award you glory points (for leveling up attributes) and gold.  Because it costs more and more glory points to level up an attribute (Ex: Level 2=1000, 3=2000, etc), it's wise to figure out what kind of fighting style you want, melee, voodoo, or rifles.  Toughness is important for staying alive and cunning helps to bypass speech checks that would save you the trouble of fighting or getting loot.  A tip is that you don't have to max out the attributes because points can be supplemented with your equipment's passive boosts, unless you want the achievement that comes with it.

Overall, I'd say give this game a chance with low expectations when it goes on sale if you're looking for a lighthearted pirate adventure with some plot twist here and there.

reviewText:
If your computer is running on a Nvidia driver, make sure 3D drivers aren't installed because the game will lag to ungodly proportions.

With that out of the way, Risen 2 is certainly not perfect but it has its charms of a pirate game.  I didn't play the first game, so I wasn't as horribly disappointed like some other fans of the first game.  The animation is cheap, but the dialogue makes up for it and the graphics itself is nice with the tropical environment.  Since blood and violence don't warrant an M rating in my book, the excessive swearing does end up warranting a mature rating as pirates use sailor's language to talking about women's bodies, shagging organisms, and the f-word like it's going out of style.  The side quests were more interesting than the main story, sadly, but side quests are fun to do since you will have to run around town quite a bit or backtrack during the main quest.

Gold is key here since combat is hard even on easy mode.  The learning curve is steep because you need to spend gold on learning how to dodge, parry, riposte, and other things.  Yes, you will have to spend a fortune to learn the skills necessary to survive.  Mashing X is going to be hard if you haven't saved money to learn how to dodge, parry, or counter attack.  A frustrating bit about the combat was that it took me a while to realize that going to the inventory to restore my health was a terrible idea, because the MC will have put away his sword and I had to quickly pull it out to guard.  But halfway through the game gets easier as you do a bunch of sidequests that award you glory points (for leveling up attributes) and gold.  Because it costs more and more glory points to level up an attribute (Ex: Level 2=1000, 3=2000, etc), it's wise to figure out what kind of fighting style you want, melee, voodoo, or rifles.  Toughness is important for staying alive and cunning helps to bypass speech checks that would save you the trouble of fighting or getting loot.  A tip is that you don't have to max out the attributes because points can be supplemented with your equipment's passive boosts, unless you want the achievement that comes with it.

Overall, I'd say give this game a chance with low expectations when it goes on sale if you're looking for a lighthearted pirate adventure with some plot twist here and there.

reviewText:
This game continues the storyline of the original Risen game.  However, they made it all Pirates of the Carribean theme, where as before, the game was dark Medieval.  I overlooked the pirate theme, but the combat system I could not.  This is an obvious console tard combat system.  Mash buttons at the right time, but even then, the animations suck and the combat is even harder and dumber than the original game, which I actually liked!  They changed too much of the game and I stopped playing after I completed the first island.  I'm not interested.  This game sucks.

Edit:
Riften 1 is a go anywhere you want, kill anyone you want type of game.  We call that non-linear.  They mimicked the Gothic play style where you feel out various factions, earn its trust, and annihilate the other faction and complete the story.  Even terrain exploration in Riften 1 is exemplorary because you can climb on roofs and obstacles and really get around obstacles, even if the developer didn't really intend for you to.  Risen 2 essentially locks you into a linear story and traps you on islands and you can't climb or escape the linearity.  I uninstalled it because of this very game mechanic.  I hate prison RPG's that pretend to be sandbox.  They feel like fetch quest games.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Most Disappointing Sequel Ever. Should probably avoid it unless you really want to continue the story or just happen to see it on sale.

Pros:
- Hilarious Dialogue

- Raiding houses, beating people up and stealing their stuff is so much fun

- Ranged Weapons are more viable in combat than they were in Risen 1

- Murdering NPCs was removed, however enemies will stay down after being beaten, until you leave the area or left-click while they are selected

- NPCs stay offended for much less time after being robbed or defeated



Cons:
- Despite being funny, dialogue is still super cringy for most of the game

- The plot from the previous game is very poorly continued, most of it is revealed from speaking to random NPCs and making certain dialogue choices later on; but some questions still have no answers

- The A.I. of both NPCs and animals is dreadful and often make clumsy decisions

- Factions are even less involved than the previous game

- Characters have paper-thin personalities, especially the bad guys who appear for barely 5 minutes and proceed to die in the least dramatic way possible

- There are now minigames, and one of them (Shooting Contest) is near impossible and if it's needed for a quest you're going to be reloading saves for a while

- Optimisation is VERY BAD. Graphics are barely a step up from Risen 1, but if you have a low-end PC and experienced near zero lag on the first game; you're still likely to get frequent game freezes on this one

- Looting NPCs after beating them up is no longer possible, thus removing plenty of quest alternatives that would have been possible in Risen 1

reviewText:
Summary: Save often if you bother trying to play this crap game.

A foul, crappy sequel.
Risen 1 was decent, showed promise.
Decent story, wonderful graphics, well done sandboxing, modest combat. A bad quest log.

Risen 2 they butchered everything.
The graphics are spoiled by the over use of lens flare.
The story basically takes what we know of Risen 1, and tells us it was nothing, meaningless, a dream.
The sandboxing is done horribly - you're on a very crappy pair of rails, and good luck trying to move outside of them.
Last and even worse, the quest system is abominable.
I didn't think it was possible to make a worse quest log than Risen 1.
They managed it in Risen 2.  Indefinate quests, poorly explained, no maps, no dots showing where to sortof head to.
Oh, and the combat system sucks ♥♥♥♥. Humans - crappy knock off of Risen 1 combat. Everything else?  special moves and pins and other BS that you can't deal with.

Lastly, open world insta-kill traps. Da fuq? Why would you put insta-kill, invisble, unseeable traps out in the open world?
In risen 1, you'll find insta kill traps flagged by cracked and damaged floor, or by vents. You may not notice, but after you reload you'll see it.
In risen 2, you're stuck - anytime you walk anywhere in the open world, there's risk of getting insta-killed by a trap.

reviewText:
Risen2: Dark Waters is an open world RPG game based around the theme of pirates. Its the sequeal to the original Risen game developed by Piranha Bytes. Risen 2 was released in early 2012 on the PC and then later released on consoles. Even today, the game is still popular among PC gamers with at least one million people owning the game on Steam alone.

This is an action RPG where you play in a third-person perspective to explore the world. You complete quests and customize your characters abilities and equipment through leveling up and assigning glory points. This takes RPG games back to their routes, allowing you to customize your character exactly how you want to play with the amount of abilities and talents on display. The combat much like Risen 1 is not exactly a strong point; it seems clunky at times, and you will often find your self dying through no fault of your own other than the strange combat system. You have two weapon slots, a melee weapon and a range weapon. You aren't able to use the range weapon unless you are within melee range of an enemy oddly yet your enemies have almost laser guided aim against you with their spears and guns.

A nice little change I found was the infinite amount of inventory space you have, some will think this removes some of the challenge of the game, but for me I have always found a limited inventory space to be a chore which is not always needed. Obviously this means that currency is never a problem once you reach the latter stages of the game since you are able to just sell everything though.

The graphics in Risen 2 are certainly an improvement on Risen 1, however there are a few glaring problems I found. The main one being the terrain pop-in throughout the open world. As you are roaming around the jungle, all of a sudden you will quite clearly notice trees and plants suddenly expanding before your very eyes. It's clear this is done to try and reduce the strain on systems for loading the world, but it is done in such an obvious way that sometimes it can ruin the immersion. I also found the game to be very very dark. The day/night circle while adds to the realism, the game is sometimes virtually unplayable in the night hours due to how dark it is. I found myself actually having to turn up the brightness settings at times to keep playing.

While the game is completely voice acted, it does have some very bad acting in it; some of the lines which are said are very out of place and just don't fit right. That being said; there are some absolute classics such as ...off
date: before I put a banana on your c*ck and call for the gorilla" being easily the best line I have heard in a video game.\n\nRisen 2 is a hard game; as you begin your adventure you will die a lot of times due to being under geared and under trained and having no money. A lot of the early quests require you to have certain training in sneaking and lock picking
recommended: which all require gold to learn
hoursPlayed: so the game starts out very slowly. I would say the first three hours are the hardest part of the game due to the speed in which you are able to carry out even the smallest side quests.\n\nThis is a well designed open world game. The world is full of life and plenty of items

reviewText: This game is FULL of bugs, broken quests, and all kinds of stuff.  BUT the game works, no crashes, and nothing game breaking it seems.  With all the auto saves even if some quest broke completely there is no need to start over.  That said this game is Piratey goodness!  Outside of the bugs, the game is so much fun, great environments, so much dialog that is good, if its not good skip it, , dont like a cinematic SKIP IT, you can just review what was said in the journal so for speed gaming it works too.  Most devs FORCE players to watch cut scenes or listen to endless dialog even today, its nice this game gives us an option to skip it, but why bother, what people say is good.  There is a Gnome island in this game, a trip into the afterlife, voodoo hoodoo shamans, a wizard, many exotic species of animals to meet and kill, all in one game!!!  This game is a must play since so far there is yet to be any well good pirate games on PC.\n\nRating  9/10  Value:  14.99

reviewText: Okay, so you're buttpirate and professional slacker, Kirby Cuddletongue, and your superiors basically tell you to go ♥♥♥♥ yourself and masquerade as an enemy to the state, just so they can finally have a reason to kick your ♥♥♥ for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in everyone's water barrels. Needless to say your love interest fights a Kraken and swims ashore after getting ship wrecked, just to meet up with you, showcasing your hardcore swaggery. Donning the legendary clothing of captain Assbeard, you take his identity and also his daughter in order to save the world from complete annihilation, while everyone else goes on about their lives as if absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing nothing happened. The game features a complete first person shooter system where you can take pot shots at flying alcohol, and the graphics engine is fully equipped with time warp technology, where vegetation smoothly phases into view from the 4th dimension.\n\nBe sure to bring your Dell Gaming Mouse and COMPAQ monitor for Tim Schafer's The Risen 2!
