reviewText:
I imagined this game would be a lot like the Gothic series. But I was disappointed. The controls are a little clunky and you don't ever get good at fighting like you could in Gothic.

My other nit-pick is the blocking. Why in the heck can you not block some of the monsters attacks? I thought maybe through upgrades it may be possible but nope. Checked online. Can't be done. You just have to take the damage and hope that you can heal later on.

I would assume the story is alright and awesome. But the beginning just drags on, and you don't really get anywhere. I only played for 2 hours before I just said Yup

hoursPlayed:
before you go to the final boss island you can't go back.
- The final boss was very anti-climatic

Other than the listed above reasons I found Risen 2 to be fairly enjoyable."

reviewText:
The game is fun, right after you start the game you feel immersed in it. The graphics are ok, but the fight mechanics are terrible. If you want to improve your damage and fight skills in game, you have to pay a lot of gold to learn them, you even have to learn how to kick an enemy (WTF)
The voice is bad synced with the mouths of the models, which is kind of annoying.
Another bad thing about the game is that they used the same face models to almost all NPC's in the game, as you go further in the game, you will start to see the same faces over and over again, but with different names and different clothes.
But still, you have a good time finishing the game.

reviewText:
Lets put it this way from the start. Pirates are more awesome than some gimpy dragon slayer in Skyrim. Plus you get to play with Voodoo and control people!

Risen 2 is more polished than the first, and got a few more great combat options. Added to that it got the oldschool gameplay difficulty like the Gothic series, so it's not a complete faceroll game.

Combat is based on either ranged or melee mostly depending on what faction you side with in the game. You have amusing abilities like Nuff Said!" where you pull out a pistol on a person during a conversation and shoot him in the head
date: or setting your parrot free to annoy and disable an opponent.\n\nOverall you play it if you liked the Gothic series

reviewText:
I really like the way that this game works.  You start out with a game that looks bad, and you can not really do anything, then just by playing, and making choices, you will find that there is actually a lot that you can do, and your skills just keep getting better.  You actually have to figure out how to use the new skills that you are taught by the various NPC's all on your own. There is no hand holding, though you do get a lot of clues if you pay attention to the NPC's, and what they tell you.

The first 6 hours or so you will be completely confused, and afraid to do much, but that will change considerably as you reach hour 8, then by 11 hours in you are able to really see the forest, and the trees.

I am 22 hours in, and having a lot of fun.  This is no AC4, but AC4 looks to have taken a lot from this game. The depth of the characters, and the story will keep me playing to the end.  Now I really want Risen 3, with this sort of open play-style, and improved graphics, and power 3 can only be incredible.

Jesse of www.Jesse.ca

reviewText:
Its a classic Piranha Bytes game that loosely ties in with the Gothic universe. Its open world with plenty of exploration featuring everything you would expect to see in a fantasy pirate RPG title.

Overall, its an average RPG. If you're into an in-depth story, this game isn't it (an element that is also lacking from the first Risen game). To be honest, I felt like that I was playing a different lead character than to the one that was present in the first installment. Piranha Bytes really needs to focus on tying everything together (like how Bioware does) if they want to taken Risen to the next level.

The other issue with Risen 2: Dark Waters is the amount of glitches that occur (to the point that its comical) and lastly, well, the combat sucks. It amounts to nothing more than spamming the mouse.

If you're going to get this game, get it when its on sale.

reviewText:
Arrrrgh! I feel so much more like a pirate playin' this game than i have ever felt in all the hours i've put into AC:Black Flag. Yeah it's true that you don't get to sail your ship as you would in BF but you spend far more of your time doing the other piraty activities that are sorely missin' from the AC game. Duelin', Drinkin', Diggin' up treasure, thevin', gettin' your monkey to do your thevin', chattin' up wenches, blowin' a guys 'ead off with your pistol in mid convo, gettin' your parrot to bug your enemies in combat and enjoyin' hours and hours of piraty conversations with the fine upstandin' gentlemen of the southern isles.

Some have critised this game for lacking the faction choices of the first game and being more linear in it's story tellin', but you can choose which islands you travel to and in which order (once you have your ship) and there's just so much stuff to do and to be gettin' on with you'll never really notice that the story is on rails.

(I will say one other critism which is the end game is buggy as sin so be aware of that before you pick up the game.)

reviewText: Amazing game. Characters are likable (even if the voice acting sucks) but all-in-all I was sad it ended. The quests are a fresh breath of air from the Fallout type of RPG games, where your hand is held throughout the entire quest. So much freedom in this RPG and the theme is better than anything else out there right now ( ZzzZZZzzz ombies....). A couple of quirks and crashes, but from a small developer that is to be expected nowadays. I doubt I'll be buying the 3rd installment just because they are getting away from the pirate theme, which is sad and upsets me. This is one hell of a gem since the vast majority never completed the game.

reviewText: Not as good as the original in almost every aspect.  Still a few too many RPG tropes to take it seriously.  The pirate setting adds some flavour to the questing and item crafting and isn't too cheesy, but I feel they could've done more with it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Risen 2: Dark Waters gets a lot of things right. For example, the game has at times near photorealistic graphics; the leveling, experience (glory) systems are well balanced; and the difficulty on medium is challenging but not frustrating. Sometimes the graphics can just be average/good but they still feel quaint. Gold seems fairly difficult to come by and also seems well-balanced. There are some neat items/equipment and skills to buy with the limited gold you have. I didn't list all the positives. The game is pick up and play friendly with a save anywhere system. Not sure if you can save during fights. I give it an 8.5/10.

reviewText: It's buggy, the melee combat is a weak clickfest, about half of the achievements are flatout broken, and the natives rely on some borderline stereotypes. This is just a joy to explore and see a wealth of hand-crafted goodness.

reviewText: After being a little bit dissapointed with the first Risen, I took my time to try the second one. I am a die hard Gothic fan and was afraid that the things that made Gothic great were long gone. Boy, was I mistaken. This game relly feels a lot like the fisrt Gothic. And that's about as high a praise as I can give a game. It's really immersive and atmospheric, you can really see that the world is not just generated but made from scratch by hand. reviewText:
I understand why this game has mixed reviews.

CONS:

1.  First the worst part of the game: the combat mechanics.  Clunky and frustrating, but can be 'finessed' by levelling up your Blades skill and getting used to the controls.  (It's also much easier once you can bring a companion.)

2.  Boring Game Design:  I understand why game designers want to prevent grinding, but gameplay and atmosphere suffer when there's little to no monster regeneration.  Clear a map and all of a sudden this once dangerous jungle is now...  empty.  Six days later- still empty.  Better game design would've been to regenerate the creatures and lower the amount of experience you get.

3.  Unbalanced Game Design: My favorite part of a RPG is getting your ♥♥♥ kicked at the beginning and slowly becoming stronger- better skills, better armor, etc.  The beginning was hard, exploration was fun, keeping track of locked chests to return to unlock later- great, but pretty early on, I acquired 90% of the equipment that I used for the entire game.  Boring.  Chest after chest and nothing good.  Tons of gold, jade, gems- but you didn't need it.  No skills that you were dying to upgrade.  No equipment to save up for.  Nobody wants to finish a RPG with 10,000,000,000 gold and 99 health potions, but it happens.  There should always be a struggle- especially towards the end.

4.  Damn you, DLC!!!  DLC should be extras- you shouldn't feel like the designers removed part of the full game to make a few extra bucks.  You have all these empty crew slots and it wasn't until the very end that I realized that those slots are for DLC characters.  I'm going towards the big battle, but I still have empty crew slots, so I get excited that there's going to be more.  There's not.  Final battle is stupid easy.  Additional crew isn't necessary.  Better equipment isn't necessary.  Higher skill levels definitely not necessary.  Game designers- It's poor game design to put a hint in the game to visit a location that's only available through DLC.  Eff you.

PROS:
that satisfying THUD when you kill a turkey
Trained Monkeys
Attack Parrots
Voodoo Dolls
Treasure Maps
Atmosphere
General Exploration
Locked Chests
Brew Alcohol / Potions
Forge Weapons
Build Guns
Create Amulets & Sceptres
Foul mouthed gnomes- F**K YES!

It was fun while it lasted- my disappointment only set in towards the end of the game.

reviewText:
Throwing in with a Piranha Bytes title, at the best of times, is a bit of a crap shoot.  Their games have been plagued from the start with programming issues and frustrating gameplay (like enemies that can just repeat-charge you to death), and yet the stories are consistently engaging, the worlds large and accessible, and the variety of progression rich.

Risen improved SOMEWHAT on the poor combat model of the Gothic franchise and Risen 2 is even more polished.  Taken by itself, it is probably the most beautiful and professional game Piranha Bytes has produced to date (Risen 3 is due out soon) and it's genuinely fun to play.  Skills are extremely varied, from having your own parrot/monkey to do your bidding to various attacks to using guns, rifles and even voodoo; Risen 2 really throws a lot of gameplay options at you and surprisingly doesn't screw up any of them.  My biggest complaint was that if you choose rifles over voodoo there isn't really much in the way of skill progression available, but that's a minor issue.

So to summarize, the game has pleasing visuals, solid gameplay and an interesting story that will take you to multiple islands and require much exploration and adventure to complete.  If you enjoyed Assassin's Creed: Black Flag for the setting you will likely enjoy this game.

I doubt I'll be buying the 3rd installment just because they are getting away from the pirate theme, which is sad and upsets me. This is one hell of a gem since the vast majority never completed the game.

reviewText:
This is one of those games where the things you don't like about it at the beginning become the things you like about it by the end.  I dont know why it has such a low score. I would give it a solid 85.

You start off on your own, pathetic at combat, easily killed. It takes a long time to level up. And unlike some games where enemies scale with you... this is one of those games where enemies are what they are from the beginning. Treasure isn't randomized. That powerful sword is in the same place with every run through.

I played the original Risen and I wasn't impressed with it. The world felt empty. There were no major decisions or plot twists. No NPC companions to play with game with.  I would not have recommended it to others. But Risen 2 is a great game that I will play a second time.

People who appreciate a good challenging RPG will appreciate this game. It has elements that I really enjoy. For example, travelling companions with unique capabilities, personalities and good voice acting. (Eventually) a homebase where you can store NPCs you don't want to travel with you. The game reminds me a little of Knights of the old Republic in that you have a list of places you need to visit and major tasks to complete, but you don't have to do them in any particular order and there are multiple ways to accomplish many of the tasks.

Things that could have been better: There was no option for controlling your companions gear other than how many health potions they had. The soundtrack was good, but short. During 40 hours, I heard the same songs repeat quite a number times.  The day night pattern was good, but the weather changes were unnatural. The game could have benefitted from more NPC romance dialogues.

reviewText:
I really like the way that this game works.  You start out with a game that looks bad, and you can not really do anything, then just by playing, and making choices, you will find that there is actually a lot that you can do, and your skills just keep getting better.  You actually have to figure out how to use the new skills that you are taught by the various NPC's all on your own. There is no hand holding, though you do get a lot of clues if you pay attention to the NPC's, and what they tell you.

The first 6 hours or so you will be completely confused, and afraid to do much, but that will change considerably as you reach hour 8, then by 11 hours in you are able to really see the forest, and the trees.

I am 22 hours in, and having a lot of fun.  This is no AC4, but AC4 looks to have taken a lot from this game. The depth of the characters, and the story will keep me playing to the end.  Now I really want Risen 3, with this sort of open play-style, and improved graphics, and power 3 can only be incredible.

Jesse of www.Jesse.ca

reviewText:
I really liked Risen 2.  When it was over, I wished there was more. I really liked the story, I liked the characters, and I loved the locations. Risen 1, on the other hand, was an ok time waster, but by the time it was over, I was really ready for it to be over (because I had gotten bored).  Get both if you can, but if I had to chose I would definitely recommend this game.

Risen 2 is set in gorgeous island jungles that feel a lot more open they actually are, and there are a good number of islands you get to visit.  Early on you are allowed to fast travel so you don't have to keep running the same paths over and over - and OVER - again (like in Risen 1).

The pirate aspect of the game is only to get a ship for transport between locations and to hold your crew (you can chose between most of them for traveling/fighting companions when you leave the ship)...there are no sea battles.  It would have been great if there were, but they had no part of the story.

There's a crafting system is based on the skills you decide to acquire and the recipes you find/pay for...you gather the materials as you play.  Money is really hard to come by in the beginning, frustratingly so...and every skill has to be bought.   I am not really thrilled with the skill system, most of the skills aren't as useful as they should be.  A number of them are really useful once or twice, but then you never need them again.  Others you want to max out as soon as possible...but you don't know which till the end of the game.  (or unless you look at a game guide)

I am also not thrilled with the fighting system.  I ended up hack and slashing despite the fact I was also supposed to be able to parry and riposte...I don't know for sure that I ever managed to...I can't swear that they actually work.  I had the same problem in Risen 1 though.  I was never sure if I was doing it right, so quit trying after a while.  Have lots potions and grog on hand.  I lived and my opponents died though, so in the end it worked out.

The game has faults but none that ever made me yell at the screen.  It was quite an enjoyable ride while it lasted.

I loved the graphics and the light- and weather effects and didn't mind the clumsy character animations. It's a fun mix of modern role play gaming with pretty old fashioned elements, both in style and execution. I think, all in all the game is just as good as Risen 1 was. For 66 hours I've had a lot of fun playing it, and look forward to playing Risen 3 soon.

reviewText:
I feel like Risen 2 is Pirhana Bytes' effort to step away from the Gothic and original Risen formula. Almost everything has been redesigned from the combat system to looting and theivery. Much of it works rather well; PB did away with shields in exchange for a more advanced sword fighting system that, unlike Gothic 3's (and to some extent Risen's), actually works. Bows and crossbows have been replaced by muskets and shotguns which some people claim are overpowered but I think they're actually weaker than the late-game bows in PB's other games and are virtually useless in close combat even with a bayonett. The inclusion of off-hand weapons adds more variety to combat allowing you to fire a pistol to finish someone off, throw sand or salt in their eyes to stun them, or cast a variety of effects with voodoo scepters and dolls.

Speaking of voodoo... I haven't played with it much but it doesn't seem to be that useful. It allows you to brew potions early in the game but there is no offensive magic in Risen 2 such as fireballs or lightning. It's all supplementary magic to help your melee combat. There are some fun things you can do like take over the body of another person or make everyone run away in terror as you throw spears into their backs, but it's a huge departure from Risen's magic system (there's also no mana).

Theivery has become somewhat of a mini game which makes it a lot more interesting IMO. You actually have to pick locks by moving the tumblers up in different orders which I suppose is just a different visual representation of Risen 1's system. The one thing about theivery I don't like in this game is that you can only pickpocket one item from very few NPC's, you don't get to pick what that item is, and it's never something you need for a quest unless the quest specifically involves pickpocketing that person. It's a good way to get extra gold and ends up paying for itself pretty early on but it isn't useful for anything else.

Another cool feature is you can train a monkey to run through smaller openings than you could get through and steal items / pull levers for you. This is a lot like Nautilus Transformation from Risen 1 but the monkey can actually interact with the environment and you have to make it come back to you to resume playing as the hero. Oh and your monkey can die. :'( You can also train a parrot to distract enemies but I haven't done that yet.

Enemies in this game are much harder than in Risen or Gothic and until you get the hang of the combat system, you will die. A lot. I remember when I first started I was getting slaughtered by Claw Monkeys and now they aren't even a concern because I know how to dodge and parry better. You will eventually face 9 foot Temple Guardians and Gargoyles that can kill you in 3 or 4 hits and you have no way of blocking their attacks, though (much like Ogres in Risen but in Risen 2 you can't dodge, only tumble away, and when you stop tumbling the enemy is already facing you and advancing again. Kinda useless).

I love everything PB has ever released with or without bugs and design flaws. The world is fun, there's tons of stuff to do, and with Risen 2 they've come a long way with dialogue and plot. Even the voice acting is getting closer to the level of bigger titles like The Elder Scrolls. I can't wait to see what Risen 3 will bring to the series!

reviewText:
The game sucks.
- Bad camera panning in and out during conversations - not smoothly, but jumping to a new zoom level by itself.
- Zooming in/out with a controller is unnecessarily complicated and does not work very well (you have to push both axis joysticks and push one forward and the other down)
- Absolutely crap sword fighting mechanics, just about the worst I saw in a game. You have just 1 basic attack and a parry mode which rarely works. No dodge ability so you have to just mash the attack button. You can get defeated by a random crab or whatever if you're unlucky to be hit constantly just when you want to attack, as it will interrupt your attack. I can't think of a game with worst combat mechanics. Oh and the pistol takes forever to reload (30-60 seconds as I recall, feels like an eternety) and often misses. Played iPhone games with better combat mechanics than this.
- Terrible, completely terrible voice acting. It's not even synced to the characters.
- Dialogues aren't that great either, the effort put into the dialogues and voices altogether is no better than on an iPhone game.
- Story isn't great and the dialogues don't help make it better.
- The main character jumps very weird. The DEV team should look into other games for how the jump should work.

Graphics are nice, except that the environment looks nicer than the characters...

Got this game in a bundle and still feels like I wasted my money.

reviewText:
Lets put it this way from the start. Pirates are more awesome than some gimpy dragon slayer in Skyrim. Plus you get to play with Voodoo and control people!

Risen 2 is more polished than the first, and got a few more great combat options. Added to that it got the oldschool gameplay difficulty like the Gothic series, so it's not a complete faceroll game.

Combat is based on either ranged or melee mostly depending on what faction you side with in the game. You have amusing abilities like Nuff Said!" where you pull out a pistol on a person during a conversation and shoot him in the head
date: or setting your parrot free to annoy and disable an opponent.\n\nOverall you play it if you liked the Gothic series

reviewText: Risen 2: Dark Waters gets a lot of things right. For example, the game has at times near photorealistic graphics; the leveling, experience (glory) systems are well balanced; and the difficulty on medium is challenging but not frustrating. Sometimes the graphics can just be average/good but they still feel quaint. Gold seems fairly difficult to come by and also seems well-balanced. There are some neat items/equipment and skills to buy with the limited gold you have. I didn't list all the positives. The game is pick up and play friendly with a save anywhere system. Not sure if you can save during fights. I give it an 8.5/10.

reviewText: It's buggy, the melee combat is a weak clickfest, about half of the achievements are flatout broken, and the natives rely on some borderline stereotypes. reviewText: This is a pretty daft game, but it has heart and is a good RPG if you don't mind the stupid somewhat childish sense of humour.  Been playing for 26 hours or so, and there's a bit of diversity, plenty of exploration, but, boy does it take time to get skilled up.  I think i paid 14 quid for this, and I'm happy with my purchase. Don't expect an elder scrolls romp, or a assassins creed game though. It's more like Two Worlds Two. Good game, loads to do, loads to explore and steal. Decent loot, and I don't mind the combat system, though I've heard people slag it off. It's basic but it gets the job done. There's a god mode too if you need it. The hero is a bit of a knob head, so you'll most likely skip all the cutscenes to save punching a hole through your screen. I'd recommend this game even so.

reviewText: Already after only a little over an hour of gameplay all that has happened is me running around on an Island killing monkeys, natives and pigs with a blunt sword and a pistol that misses at point blank all while I'm half naked. Bought it with Risen since both were on sale for only $9.99 (with DLCs) so I figured why not.  The combat is very clunky, and it feels like the blocking doesn't even work and the keys magicly don't respond when I need to press them. All over that starting island I kept running into traps and when I tried to avoid them, still got caught. This game has ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off more than War Thunder in an incredibly short amount of time. Most of the dialouge is boring and the voice acting makes me cringe at times and there are moments I don't have a clue as to what they're trying to say with their pseudo-english styled accents (I hate having to rely in captions).\n\nPlus side is the graphics and an interesting story with a very unique setting.

reviewText:
It is a very enjoyable and immersive rpg with some flaws.

I had a great time with it. The exploration, the atmosphere and the quests are really well done and keep you interested until the end of the game.

The game has some bugs, also it's fighting system is not so good and not a hardcore rpg as the first Risen was. But if you can forgive these things, you will love Risen 2.

And yes, the story is better than in Risen 1. It's not on the level of the Witcher by any means but it has it's moments.
It is not a pirate simulator. You can't control your ship, trade or whatever. It is an rpg with pirate theme and Piranha nailed the pirate thing very well.

It is a love or hate game so if you are not sure, try the demo first. It will give you a clear picture how Risen 2 is.
For me an 8/10, but I didn't care the obvious flaws to much.

reviewText:
I recommend this title to all the people who do not hate themselves enough in their daily lives.

Really! You need to be taken down to reality again? You struggle with the feeling of too much self-worth? You suffer from the nausea of being too happy with how things are going? You haven't thought of cutting of your nose for two days because life's just so great? This is it! The solution for all your ailments.

That is to say the game itself is actually not that bad. If you liked the old Gothic games back in the day then let me tell you, the atmosphere is just the same. The problem is, Risen 2 is just horribly executed. And it has innumerable details that just make the pus in my abscesses boil with uncontrolled rage. It begins with no slots for auto- and quicksaves, which starts you of with 424 savegames more and three gigabytes hdd space less after 51 minutes, crosses over to an utterly ♥♥♥♥ed up combat system and leaves you with laughable animations. Now, I don't need no fancy graphics to enjoy me a nice slice of videogame since I'm blind anyway and only play by sound but if the running of your mighty pirate looks like he either has to ♥♥♥♥ like a hipster with an exploded bladder or has a wooden lower leg that has been glued to his knee with the pus from my abscesses than you cannot help but stare at it. All. The. ♥♥♥♥ing. Time.

Also, it seems that some of the achievements are broken so if you're a chievo-♥♥♥♥♥ like me you get some extra ground for raging. It's a full service packet!

I paid 7.50 bucks in the summer sale and that's 5 too much. I still play it though. Why? Because I felt rather good the last few days and I can't live with myself if I'm in such a state...

reviewText: ok well this game relies on two things to enjoy. One is patience the early part of the game is slow dull and due to the cool idiea of needing to buy skills to use them unforgiving. Your goal in the start is not going to be one of stop the evil it will be find all the stuff to steal to get money to get skills to steal more to then fight the giants. Second thing you need is to understand that the game is very much story run you are not going to be trown out to see it all from the word go like many games let you do now and if you try you will learn that the great pirate is very crap when dealing with savages and animals. But once it gets going it gets good. get the right skills and learn to manage your stuff and you will have fun. it does well with making you feel like a pirate as you go through. Now understand this is not Black Flag but it is good and if you can get through that first island you will have a lot of fun.

reviewText: This game started out as a big disappointment. I almost uninstalled after the first 30 minutes, but I'm glad I stuck with it! After playing for several hours the charms begin to reveal themselves, and the game's strengths and addictive qualities really start to shine through. Its weaknesses are fairly obvious from the beggining, and include poor graphics in some areas, particularly with NPC models. Other weaknesses include poor scripting, player-character immersion, and a general feeling of frustration due to unpolished content. There were a lot of great ideas not fully exploited. However, the RPG adventure with the pirate theme, with ships, crew, treasures, and some particularly hilarious gnomes, made this a worthy investment. After almost 62 hours of gameplay, I have not a single regret.\n\nRisen 2 is difficult to score. I'd have to give it a 7 out of 10 overall, but there are times during the game when you'll swear it deserves a 9. I'd recommend it to any RPG fan.

reviewText: Starting out a journey as an undercover pirate and finishing it with your own crew and a ship, you can expect a lot of fun from this game. It doesn't go any near the grand epicness of games like The Witcher 2 or the like of it, but it certainly has a lot to offer. Be prepared for a regular Piranha Bytes like gameplay, as all that makes the game different from Gothic is the story and the setting. The game is definitely good looking and has some nice tunes to play to, but overall you wouldn't say it's an AAA quality product. In general, it feels like an indie RPG, different from other games (except PB games) and definitely with some fresh ideas and a good plot. Worth a shot, get it now if you simply like a good adventure or wait for a Steam sale if you have a better game in mind. If you spend a good deal exploring and get all the DLC, you'll find yourself in a 30 - 35 hour game with amazing atmosphere and sense of exploration.

reviewText: Risen 2: Dark Waters is a decent Gothic-like RPG, don't get me wrong there, but it just don't live up to the quality levels of the previous Piranha Bytes. Even though the first installment of the past-Gothic franchise was not especially great, it had some great elements and in overall, it benefited mostly from the vibe of the original trilogy of games. However, this does not apply in most parts to the sequel which felt like a cheap stuffing made on a tight budget, where the pirate theme as well as pirate stereotypes did not help. Bad character animation, and relatively short single player campaign filled with rather simplistic quest design did nothing to drag the game out of the mediocre.\n\nSo to keep it short - Risen 2 is a mediocre RPG, which is at parts relatively fun, but does nothing new, inventive or worthwhile. You will play it once and then forget all about it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Risen 2 is the sequel to Risen and, personally, I enjoy it much more than the first. The combat has improved; albeit, not by much. You are the same exact character as you were in the first game, you don't get much exposition as to what happened in the previous game so hopefully you can do as I did and finish the first Risen before playing this.
This sequel to the Gothic successor is another great action RPG for fans of cult-hit games that many people seem to just dislike simply because they only care about AAA titles but seem to buy other games just to rag on them.

Simply put: Risen 2 is the Pirate Action RPG that no one asked for and nobody knew that they wanted. It is a very fun game and I just love allocating my skill points, you don't get XP, you get GLORY! Little things like that, make this game well worth while and a fun experience for Action RPG fans to enjoy. If you're into games that don't look amazing or control super smoothly (IE: Splatterhouse, Venetica, BloodRayne, Way of the Samurai, The Force Unleashed, Of Orcs and Men, etc.) then this is an excellent choice.

PROS:
+ Great Pirate game
+ Fun action RPG
+ Graphics look pretty good
+ Animations, though clunky, look alright
+ Good soundtrack
+ A lot of fun side-quests
+ Improved combat
+ Weapon system and equipment are good to use
+ Easy to learn
+ That water sure is pretty
+ A good story worth telling and worth listening to

CONS:
- Voice acting not so great
- Combat still kinda clunky
- Some characters are annoying
- Sometimes feels a little too linear
- Frustratingly easy to die at some times
- Traps can one hit kill you
- Animations can be clunky
- So many jagged edged
- Still no swimming, curse those dangerous waters

reviewText:
sadly, this game was not as good as the first Risen. still good... but it has a lot of flaws.

first of all, they kept main characters and plot, while moving from a sword-and-sorcery setting to one with guns and cannon, and moved to a carribean pirate aesthetic that really does not fit the feel of the previous game.

second, the theme of the game is 'pirate', but a lot of that feels forced, like a checklist of tropes. there is no real 'choice', merely a rollercoaster. the only decision point worth noting is if you want to train voodoo or not.

aside from that the game is also a bit buggy at times, and got stuck in the middle of the final bossfight.

good overall, but it has its flaws. also, the skill system in this one is crap.

reviewText:
***I've edited this review after completing the game. See further *** markings below.

As of being halfway through Risen 2, it is my opinion that while this game does have some minor to moderate issues that affect gameplay, there's still enough meat in the game to keep me playing.

Weaknesses:

Graphics performance: this game has optimization issues. By no means do I have a beast machine (3rd gen i7, Intel HD Graphics 4000, 8 GB RAM), but Saints Row IV runs faster for me than this game does; I've not had a moment of smooth movement for ~15 hours of gameplay, and that's on low graphic settings. I usually don't let graphics get in the way of my gaming, but for a 2012 game, I at least expect a decent frame rate if the graphics are going to be sub-par for its era.

Camera and Mouse Sensitivity
I'm lumping these two together because Risen 2 makes a strange relationship between these two things. First, there is NO mouse sensitivity--your only option for what is a ridiculously high default camera movement speed is to lower that, but you're not out of the woods. Mouse sensitivity is really high for menus, dialogue, and some minigames. The mouse sensitivity is particularly an awful experience when in some minigames, like the shooting range; the only option you have to try and keep your sanity is to lower the game's difficulty to slow everything but your cursor down.

Perspective
The player's perspective throughout the game is a touch annoying at times; you can never look up, and trying to line yourself up right to notice items on the ground, on tables, or next to sleeping NPCs that will murder you if you wake them can be an unreasonably frustrating part of this game.

***Combat: This game's combat system is horrible. The game clearly tries to create a complex system for swordplay, but guess what? You won't be needing it, and you won't want to use it, either. Advanced swordplay techniques can't be used on monsters, so there's more than half of the enemies in the game you don't get to use that with, but there's an even bigger reason not to use swordplay: GUNS. Guns are SO OVERPOWERED that once you start, you'll never go back. A half decent rifle and pistol ensures victory over every enemy with a hit-and-run approach. It should not be up to the player to make the game more interesting for themselves--this game fails to make combat interesting.

***Bugs and glitches: And here we are, the reason I came back to edit my review. The bugs and glitches in this game are the worst I've personally experienced. I should not need to worry about a boss disappearing while still holding loot I need. I should not have to use the in-game console to grant myself said item. There are so many little things here and there that are broken that the overall gaming experience drastically declines--you are playing a broken game, and it doesn't feel good after the time this game takes to complete.

Strengths:

***Difficulty: Technical issues aside, this game is actually difficult--until you get access to guns. I will congratulate this game for making difficulty a strength early game, but the game doesn't adapt to the weapons you later get access to--you'll eventually dominate everything because the game does nothing to challenge you further than it does from the start.

Culture and humor: The pirate culture of Risen 2 is really entertaining. While the voice acting isn't always awesome, the content of what you hear usually sticks pretty true to what we think pirates said and did. The humor is also fairly rich for a game that doesn't seem to have the best writers ever; I caught myself laughing a tad uncontrollably once or twice. I'll give the game that much.

Final say:
This is a game that is close to doing many things right but leaves nothing polished. My first pass at this review happened halfway through the game, and now that I've finished it, I can confidently denounce this game. If you already have it, don't waste your time, and if you don't, don't buy it.

reviewText:
I didn't listen to them. I didn't listen to those reviews saying that this game is bad. I had to play this.

All i can say is this: this game gave me a hell of a journey. I duelled with pirates, soldiers of the inquisition and native warriors alike. I killed more rats and giant crabs than i can count. I possessed a native and attempted to speak in his native tongue to his peers (albeit very badly). All those hours i've spent into this game, it all leads to a duel with none other than the titan lord, Mara. In the end, i was rewarded with that nice little end game music that made the hair on the back of my neck stand on end. It kinda reminds me of Kai's work somehow, from the Gothic series.

Sure, the plot might be lacking, the combat system feels more like a button mashing puzzle minigame which mostly relies on timing and the game itself is glitchy, i enjoyed it despite all that. If you're like me and you like the old Gothic series i'd say go ahead and play this game. Do not heed the bad reviews and most definitely do not listen to that silly excuse of a video by AngryJoe. They cant seem to enjoy the little rpg titles like this and Gothic just because the experience is rough in the beginning, if you know what i'm saying. A few flaws wont make this game bad, in my opinion. This title deserves to stand between the 1st Risen and Risen 3, even though it lacks a bit in a few areas.

I guess i'll give it an 7/10

Also, you can earn glory by killing rats, so that's a 1+

reviewText:
I greatly enjoyed the first game of the series, even though it had a few nasty progess-blocking quest bugs. So I was excited to play this pirate-filled sequel. But any virtues the game might have possessed were overshadowed by my feeling uncomfortable playing it. I couldn't enjoy the roleplaying experience soon after arriving at the Sword Coast, and just put the game down.

If they were going for a level of social authenticity with the rampant racism, they definitely nailed it. Unfortunately I can't enjoy a roleplaying game where the protagonists are violently racist.

The first instance that really surprised me was when you meet the governor of Tacarigua, an obviously corrupt and shady character. He requests you to bring him the heads of some escaped slaves. His character is further proven as he regards them as completely sub-human when you express doubt about his goals. Oh boy!" I thought
date: "I can't wait to side with these natives against this horrible governor!" But no
recommended: not an option. This side quest has only one possible outcome: murder the escaped slaves for the governor.\n\nThat was just one optional side-quest though
hoursPlayed: and I was enjoying the game play and other quests well enough
voteText: so I continued on with optimism that I could still be a good guy. Until the Sword Coast.\n\nWhere we encountered some natives who'd allied with Crow's men. Not an optional part of the plot. And I don't expect every colored person in this white-dominated game to be a good guy
helpfulPercent: so natives I had to attack wasn't the problem. The problem was with what Patty said. The protagonist says
votesHelpful: "What does that mean?" in response to one of the natives speaking a foreign language. To which Patty replies
votesTotal: "It means first we kill the idiot that doesn't speak our language."\n\nI was shocked and disappoitned at the racism coming from a major ally NPC. I realized then that these were protagonists I wasn't going to be able to enjoy playing
votesFunny: and I put the game down. It's a shame
commentsCount: because I enjoyed many other aspects of the game. But I don't recommend it for anyone who might share racial and sociopolitical sensitivities. The protagonists are just not worth rooting for."

reviewText:
This is the only open world western-style-pirate-rpg that exists. It is a recommended buy for that thing alone. I compare it with Bound by Flame or Bioware rpg-s. The swashbuckling pirate atmosphere is pulled off perfectly with jungle settings, voodoo magic and mysterious forgotten temples full of monsters and traps. Which is the reason why you should buy this game - because of the atmosphere! You are free to roam the seas and interact with characters and on board your own ship and embark on sidequests or follow the be-the hero-and-save-the-world type main quest. The combat is bad, not terrible and takes a bit of patience to get around to, but this is offset by the perfect pirate atmosphere and pirete dialogue. I raised only social and non-combat skills through maybe 75% of the game and I had no problem getting through the rest. Besides being social, sneaking and piratting is what this game does well, so that is what you want to focus on, not the hokum combat.

It is unique - buy it!

reviewText:
I love the Risen games, probably because I’m primarily an Explorer, with a minor in Completionist.  In both Risen and Risen 2, you’re rewarded for exploring.  Quite often with actual loot, but in a more general sense with the same feeling you get when visiting a natural landmark or castle for the first time in real life.  I’m not saying the graphics are photorealistic (though Piranha Bytes’ use of lighting and sound does a lot to mask any deficiencies in the objects themselves), but what stands out to me is the world design.  So many game maps seem designed to fit the mission, but in Risen it feels as though a game was laid on top of a pre-existing world that follows natural laws of geology.  From the mountains and caves to the rivers and shores, the terrain feels natural instead of gamey.  I’ve played a lot of games where the design of a particular location was good enough for the memory of a specific location to stick with me -- but in other games I remember an interesting map, whereas in Risen my memory catalogues it as an interesting place.

No Risen review would be complete without a mention of combat.  Yes, it’s darn tough at the beginning.  I mean really tough.  A pair of wild boars hardly considers you a danger when you first start out.  But if you are patient, make use of your companions, and admit that a low-level adventurer needs to run away sometimes, your power will grow over time to a point where only the most dreadful monsters are challenging.  The magic of this is that you actually get a sense of your character’s increasing talents.  And, unlike some games where a numeric increment is all you get when you level, in Risen you actually get new abilities as well as improving old ones.  By the time the end of the game nears, you’ll smile when you meet up with any pesky boars, and you’ll think, “Only two?”

The Good:
World design: terrain, light, sound, music.  The world builders are clearly familiar with geology and history.
Exploration is rewarded.
Actual sense of progression as your character gains experience.
Wry sense of humour without being too adolescent.
While the overall story isn’t terribly innovative, there were enough twists to keep it interesting.  The smaller NPC-related arcs were definitely above average.  I also found it interesting that they went for an adult rating solely based on dialogue, and not the more sensationalist paths of gore or nudity.
Unlimited inventory space!  So nice not to have to micromanage bags.
Treasure maps!  Who doesn’t like treasure maps?
The Bad:
A number of non-game-breaking bugs, like rain not appearing after loading a previous save, a companion getting stuck on a roof, or an ability not showing up as being learned in your skills display even though your character can perform that action.
NPCs with short memories: you can steal from them, defeat them in a fight, and a moment later they will still happily trade with you.  Also, some NPCs never sleep.  Really, never.
Some abilities not explained well.
Some instances where if you don’t do x before y, you can never do x again.  There was one NPC who was the only one who could train you in certain skills, but after you’ve reached a certain point in the story he won’t train you anymore and just talks about the final boss fight.
One clue to treasure that made no sense outside the German version.
[I feel I should note that my play time, which is only for a single playthrough, is a good deal longer than the minimum required to finish the game.  This is because when I visit a world that is this rich in detail, I don’t make my character run unless there is a reason he would do so in the game, and I don’t use quick travel unless there is a plot reason for it (e.g. magical crystals).  Risen 2 has very generous quick travel, but I preferred walking everywhere to soak in the lush scenery.]

reviewText: This is a pretty daft game, but it has heart and is a good RPG if you don't mind the stupid somewhat childish sense of humour.  Been playing for 26 hours or so, and there's a bit of diversity, plenty of exploration, but, boy does it take time to get skilled up.  I think i paid 14 quid for this, and I'm happy with my purchase. Don't expect an elder scrolls romp, or a assassins creed game though. It's more like Two Worlds Two. Good game, loads to do, loads to explore and steal. Decent loot, and I don't mind the combat system, though I've heard people slag it off. It's basic but it gets the job done. There's a god mode too if you need it. The hero is a bit of a knob head, so you'll most likely skip all the cutscenes to save punching a hole through your screen. I'd recommend this game even so.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I can't help it, I just love this style of role play games. I've very much enjoyed Risen 1, and even though many disliked the pirate setting with firearms and voodoo stuff, I didn't mind them at all in Risen 2. It was great fun for me to explore the islands, hunt for loot, I liked the flat dialogs with the even more flat humor. I loved the graphics and the light- and weather effects and didn't mind the clumsy character animations. It's a fun mix of modern role play gaming with pretty old fashioned elements, both in style and execution. I think, all in all the game is just as good as Risen 1 was. For 66 hours I've had a lot of fun playing it, and look forward to playing Risen 3 soon.

reviewText:
I really liked Risen 2.  When it was over, I wished there was more. I really liked the story, I liked the characters, and I loved the locations. Risen 1, on the other hand, was an ok time waster, but by the time it was over, I was really ready for it to be over (because I had gotten bored).  Get both if you can, but if I had to chose I would definitely recommend this game.

Risen 2 is set in gorgeous island jungles that feel a lot more open they actually are, and there are a good number of islands you get to visit.  Early on you are allowed to fast travel so you don't have to keep running the same paths over and over - and OVER - again (like in Risen 1).

The pirate aspect of the game is only to get a ship for transport between locations and to hold your crew (you can chose between most of them for traveling/fighting companions when you leave the ship)...there are no sea battles.  It would have been great if there were, but they had no part of the story.

There's a crafting system is based on the skills you decide to acquire and the recipes you find/pay for...you gather the materials as you play.  Money is really hard to come by in the beginning, frustratingly so...and every skill has to be bought.   I am not really thrilled with the skill system, most of the skills aren't as useful as they should be.  A number of them are really useful once or twice, but then you never need them again.  Others you want to max out as soon as possible...but you don't know which till the end of the game.  (or unless you look at a game guide)

I am also not thrilled with the fighting system.  I ended up hack and slashing despite the fact I was also supposed to be able to parry and riposte...I don't know for sure that I ever managed to...I can't swear that they actually work.  I had the same problem in Risen 1 though.  I was never sure if I was doing it right, so quit trying after a while.  Have lots potions and grog on hand.  I lived and my opponents died though, so in the end it worked out.

The game has faults but none that ever made me yell at the screen.  It was quite an enjoyable ride while it lasted.

reviewText:
Not A Worthy Sequel

If you were a big fan of Risen and looking for more of the same with Risen 2 you're going to be disappointed. While there are plenty of locations to explore, treasure to find, NPCs to interact with and enemies to slay, the core gameplay mechanics revolving around combat have taken several steps backwards. Gone is the fluid and intuitive combat that Risen boasted, where a combination of player skill, character stats and gear met that allowed one to tackle the most dangerous enemies in the game from the start if they had the skill and timing to back it up. Melee combat was very much like Gothic 1/2 or Dark Souls 1 in that way. You also had magic and ranged weaponry which were both highly effective if one desired that approach.

Risen 2 does away with skill-based melee combat, featuring stilted, often broken animations and combat reduced to you and your foe hacking away at one another until one dies with a token dodge thrown in here or there. Magic is gutted and beyond worthless, and ranged weapons (guns) are extremely powerful to the point of trivializing the entire game.

That said, if you're willing to overlook the atrocious downgrade combat has taken and want to see how the story plays out, it's worth a playthrough; but keep your expectations low.

Final Score - 6.5/10

reviewText:
The best game of the Risen series in my opinion.

If you read my other reviews, you may have noticed that I love atmospheric games. I love games with immersion and a fascinating storyline. And Risen 2 does a great job at delivering this.

First of all the pirates setting of the game is great. It's good to see that the devs have gone away from the magic theme of the first game and made something more interesting (I still like Risen 1 don't get me wrong). Instead of one big island there are now several smaller ones you can head for on your own pirate ship. There also are new weapons like pistols and muskets. Furthermore you can learn voodoo magic from the tribal guys in the jungle, unearth treasures, loot dangerous ruins, drink rum and grog - just pirate things. I love it!

The graphics and the graphical effects are stunning. It's not to colorful (like Risen 3), not to grey, just right. And especially the creatures look great and realistic because of high resolution sprites. The only graphical letdown are the NPCs: Many of them look alike, their eyes are a bit too glossy and stuff like that.

The graphical and weather effects as well as the sound effects are doing a great job at adding to the atmosphere. Especially rain and storms are really heavy and atmospheric.

The main characters are charismatic. Every crew member has their strengths and weaknesses which makes them believable. Voice acting is above average.

But the combat system is crap and by far the biggest letdown of the game. It's worse than Risen 1's combat system (Risen 3's is even worse!). Ok, it's a Piranha Bytes game but still.. this is awful. But luckily there are companions in this game, so it's playable. Seriously now, it's not that bad if you get used to it. You may need some time but it's well spend, believe me.

Conclusion:All Risen and Gothic games have a certain something that makes them so extremly immersive. They are all great in some way but also have severe flaws. Despite the bad combat system, I think Risen 2 is a gem. The setting is great. The atmosphere is great. The story is ok.

Buy the Gold Editon! The DLCs are nice, you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Risen 2 is a great game. That's at least my opinon.
You can try to skill yourslef as a blades, marksman, or cunning thieve pirate - that uses dirty tricks - or even a vodoo casting character.
It has a great (Pirate) story and inbetween exploring the maps and fighting there is much to do. You can craft various staff, like blades, guns or potions. You can dig up treasure, solve sidequest...lots to do.
Try to sneak into a house when the owner is asleep and rob him via minigame lockpicking a chest etc. Or even better use your monkey (if you trained that skill) to rob the place. There ar drinking contest or shooting minigames aswell!

Granted its not as good as Risen I but i still enjoy the game.
After hours of playing (i am not even into half the game) there is still plenty of content waiting.
So you have to invest some time.
I especially laughed my ♥♥♥ of when i first met the gnomes on the Isle of the thieves...but i won't spoiler the fun for you :)
Combat is the only downside it is especially hard to do ripostes. It nevertheless is fun to offhand throw salt into the enemies face, or shoot him with a pistol etc.

i give Risen 2 a 8/10

reviewText:
After completing the game, I have mixed feelings.

First, you can't take this game seriously. It's got intricacies and bugs like none other. Everyone talks like they're speaking sign language. You will complete missions before you are given them. At times, you will breeze through the combat. Other times, you will fire 180 degrees away from the enemies, roll into attacks, and instead of casting or shooting, the character will put down their weapon. Fighting is fun when it works. A lot of the time, it doesn't.

You are constantly picking flowers, and you can't help but look like a pansy. Cutscenes will skip without your consent. You can beat people up, rob them blind, and STILL they'll help you a few moments later. You recover healh slowly by eating food and quickly by drinking booze or sleeping on a random bed you happen across out in the open in the jungle. Auto-save will happen about once every 5 minutes to 3 hours.

You spend the whole game searching for amulets to defeat the ultimate evil... but in the end you don't really ever use them. The second to last boss will be unreachable for most of the game, but every 12 seconds will alternate between using the same predictable attack, and opening itself for retaliation... A leviathan monster, the Kraken, capeable of sinking ships.The rest of the time... you wait.

But, it's all-in-all, a pretty alright RPG. You have the leveling system, unlocking abilities, a choice between two factions, a gaggle of creatures with varying abilities, minigames. It's all nothing new, nothing you haven't seen plenty of times elsewhere. But it was still fun.

reviewText:
Risen 1 was good, not perfect, but good. This might be the first game when PB ( the developers) goes away from the gothic formula. This game has  new mechanics which more or less work...

But they delete  elements from the first game like shield blocking against animals, magic(replaced by voodoo spells), archery replaced by some guns which  are alright (I quess)

-Voodoo spells are mostly use to make some story missions a lot easier, sometimes in combat but they aren't game changing, kinda a wasted effort but the story bits were cool.

-Hand guns are used like in MMORPGs , click on something and you have a chance to crit/miss. I don't have a big experience with muskets.

-Story-wise the plot from the first game is kinda ♥♥♥♥ed and no one basically gave a damn, there is a wiki page with the backstory from the developers but besides that this game tolds a whole different story. BUT I kinda liked this story more, the dialogues are funnier.

-Combat is ...bad. It's more of the *click click click* thing than the *swing right block swing left advance dodge*. Sometimes you lose without even knowing what you did wrong. There is a block button but it's mediocre at best.

Overall while not a very good I think is something worth your time : especially if you get the chance to get the whole risen pack with like 15$ like I did.

6/10

reviewText:
I liked this game, but would only recomend it if you played and liked the first game in the series. All three games are like a single story and I think if I had played this one first I would not have enjoyed it as much.

Like all deepsilvers openworld RPG's it has the same issues, bad combat mechanics, and a bunch of random quests and a few factions. So if thats not your bag you can move on

The biggest issue however is the game freezing, there seems to be a memory issue or something, the longer you play the more it slowis down the game until it freezes, I basically set a timer and would quit back to the start menu every hour or so to get around this.

reviewText: I'm sorry PB but I cant understand the need for the change of theme from Risen 1 to this game. I just dont feel that the Pirate theme was a good idea and as someone who loved Risen 1 I felt really letdown by this sudden change which I didnt feel was either wanted or required. Secondly I really dont like combat in this game and feel this was the area from the original they should have been focussing on improving rather than the theme, combat just feels clunky and the progression system means in the early game you will suffer but by late game its all a bit to easy. Suffice to say I didnt enjoy fighting which proves to be a significant issue. I also really didnt like how the magic is completely replaced by Voo Doo which doesnt feel like its properly balanced. Lastly I did notice some performance issues whilst playing this game.\n\nIMO Risen 2 and 3 are very average offerings and I would instead recommend playing the original Risen unless you really have a thing for cheesy pirates.
